Creative efforts will bring results because your imagination will also soar.</p><h2>Virgo (Aug. 23-Sept. 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> In the next decade, Neptune will be traveling through one of your money houses, which can create confusion. Therefore, be extra cautious about your financial dealings with others (especially if you think something looks dicey). Be careful gambling or being swindled. Caution.</p><h2>Libra (Sept. 23-Oct. 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Neptune will be opposite your sign for the next decade, creating confusion in your closest relationships. It also can contribute to fatigue and iron deficiency. Take care of yourself. Be clear in all your communications. Don’t leave anyone in doubt about your intentions.</p><h2>Scorpio (Oct. 23-Nov. 21)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Today, Neptune moves into Aries, which is something no one alive today has ever experienced. It could create confusion in health issues as well as your job. You might feel disillusioned with what you're doing and want to seek work that benefits others.</p><h2>Sagittarius (Nov. 22-Dec. 21)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Artists will flourish in the next decade because Neptune will increase your ability to visualize and imagine to a much greater degree. You will also become more romantically idealistic, which could create disappointment because you might expect someone to live up to your ideal of perfection. (Not going to happen.)</p><h2>Capricorn (Dec. 22-Jan. 19)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Today, Neptune is moving into Aries, which you have never experienced before in your life. This could encourage confusion on the home front in the next decade. Communications with parents might be challenged. You will also want to create your ideal home, and your urge to do this will start to grow.</p><h2>Aquarius (Jan. 20-Feb. 18)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Today Neptune changes signs, which means your communications with others in the next decade will be affected. Be careful how you talk to others. Be as clear as possible because serious misunderstandings might occur. Don't let your imagination interfere with the facts.</p><h2>Pisces (Feb. 19-March 20)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Be careful with your financial dealings in the next several years because fuzzy Neptune is entering your house of money and possessions, which can create confusion. It might tempt you to gamble. (Not good.) Avoid risky schemes and protect your best interests.</p><h2>If today is your birthday</h2><p>Singer-songwriter Robbie Williams (1974) shares your birthday today. You're quick-witted, extroverted, and sensation-seeking, as well as bold, imaginative, and trendsetting. This is a year of teaching and learning. Take time to renew your spiritual or religious beliefs. Explore philosophies that give you better self-awareness and bring you closer to the true meaning of your life.</p>
entries.author: Georgia Nicols

entries.title: Trump EPA set to repeal scientific finding that's basis for U.S. climate change policy
entries.summary: <p>WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Thursday revoked a scientific finding that long has been the central basis for U.S. action to regulate greenhouse gas emissions and fight climate change, the most aggressive move by the Republican president to roll back climate regulations.</p><p>The rule finalized by the Environmental Protection Agency rescinds a 2009 government declaration known as the endangerment finding that determined that carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases threaten public health and welfare. The Obama-era finding is the legal underpinning of nearly all climate regulations under the Clean Air Act for motor vehicles, power plants and other pollution sources that are heating the planet.</p><p>The repeal eliminates all greenhouse gas emissions standards for cars and trucks and could unleash a broader undoing of climate regulations on stationary sources such as power plants and oil and gas facilities, experts say. Legal challenges are near certain.</p><p>President Donald Trump called the move “the single largest deregulatory action in American history, by far,” while EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin called the endangerment finding “the Holy Grail of federal regulatory overreach.”</p><p>Top Illinois Democrats, including U.S. Sens. Dick Durbin and Tammy Duckworth, joined 47 other Senate Democrats last September to oppose the Trump administration’s effort to roll back the foundational climate rule.</p><p>“This disastrous decision reverses decades of progress and ignores decades of legal and scientific precedent, and its negative impacts won’t just be felt immediately, but for generations to come as well,” the U.S. Senate Environmental Justice Caucus, which Duckworth co-chairs, said in a statement. “It’s yet another Trump-created disaster for American families, all to line his billionaire donors’ pocketbooks, as Americans pay the price.”</p><p>The Sierra Club filed the original lawsuit that established the scientific finding more than 20 years ago. Jack Darin, director of the Illinois chapter of the environmental advocacy organization, said that state action is more relevant than ever.</p><p>“Illinois must continue to lead the way,” he said.</p><p>Trump called the endangerment finding “one of the greatest scams in history,” claiming falsely that it “had no basis in fact” or law. “On the contrary, over the generations, fossil fuels have saved millions of lives and lifted billions of people out of poverty all over the world,” Trump said at a White House ceremony, although scientists across the globe agree that carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases are driving catastrophic heat waves and storms, droughts and sea level rise.</p><p>Environmental groups described the move as the single biggest attack in U.S. history against federal authority to address climate change. Evidence backing up the endangerment finding has only grown stronger in the 17 years since it was approved, they said.<br>“This action will only lead to more climate pollution, and that will lead to higher costs and real harms for American families,” said Fred Krupp, president of Environmental Defense Fund, adding that the consequences would be felt on Americans’ health, property values, water supply and more.</p><p><i>Matthew Daly is an Associated Press writer. Juanpablo Ramirez-Franco is WBEZ Environment reporter, Grist.</i></p>
entries.author: Juanpablo Ramirez-Franco | WBEZ

entries.title: Democrats have a chance to pounce
entries.summary: <p>President Donald Trump's approval rating is sinking and gasping for air. His average net approval stands at negative 13.7, which is lower than Joe Biden's was at this point in his term. This matters beyond cosmic justice: The president's approval rating is the best predictor of midterm election outcomes. When it falls below 50%, his party tends to lose seats, as in the 1982, 1994, 2006, 2010, 2014 and 2018 elections.</p><p>So the Democratic Party, written off as dead by some a few months ago, stands poised for victory in November. That's good, but not good enough.</p><p>The stakes are so high that a win isn't sufficient to meet the moment. We need a crushing repudiation of this fascistic horror show.</p><p>The easiest issue, perhaps surprisingly, is immigration. Since 2024, Democrats have been snakebit on the subject, afraid that their instinctive pro-immigrant positions were unpopular enough to lead voters to select a snarling villain vowing mass deportations. They can exhale. What the polls over the last year suggest is that most Americans are not white-supremacist goons like Stephen Miller, ready to trash the Constitution in the name of purifying <i>die Volk</i>.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-d10000" name="module-d10000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Columnist </div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Columnist</div> </div><p>Instead, voters actually believed that Trump would only deport "the worst of the worst." As they watched the inhuman treatment of gardeners, veterans, children and American citizen protesters, they soured fast. After the shooting of Alex Pretti, fully 60% of respondents told NBC they disapproved of Trump's immigration policies, 49% strongly so.</p><p>If Democrats present themselves as opposing the brutal tactics of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement and Customs and Border Protection and favoring firm border controls, they should find themselves in the sweet spot. Messages like Billie Eilish's "No one is illegal on stolen land" are unhelpful. By all means, get angry about the savagery; stress that law and order means that first and foremost the state cannot be the lawbreaker. But also add that borders are not notional, and chaos cannot be permitted to prevail along the Rio Grande.</p><p>The other big issue on voters' minds is inflation, or "affordability." The reality is that politicians cannot actually bring prices down, as Trump promised to do in 2024, except by crashing the economy. Still, some voters presumably believed him, and they are disillusioned now. Some Democrats may be tempted to run on taxing the rich. This is a comfortable old shoe for Democrats, but as a political strategy it hasn't been terribly successful. Middle-class voters often fear that they will be labeled as rich.</p><p>On the other hand, voters have already concluded that tariffs are making life more expensive. The issue is a layup — if Democrats can get out of their own way. Nearly 60% of Americans blame Trump for rising prices, and 65% disapprove of his tariffs. Fifty-nine percent of independent voters say the tariffs have hurt the economy and their personal finances. Voters are rarely able to connect policy to outcomes, but they have done so in the case of tariffs. Back in 2024, Americans were about equally divided on the question of trade, with some favoring higher tariffs and roughly similar numbers opting for lower tariffs. Experience has changed their views.</p><p>The progressive wing of the party has long favored tariffs as a way to protect American workers from competition from low-wage nations. This muddies the waters.</p><p>Cutting tariffs is one of the only levers governments can pull that will actually reduce prices, and since price sensitivity is very much on voters' minds, does it make sense to temper that message at all? All House Democrats voted in favor of a resolution that would end the national emergency excuse for tariffs, and three Republicans joined them. This is the moment. Tariffs are bad — full stop.</p><p>Finally, a vulnerability that Democrats must overcome is seeming to be soft on crime. Here again the Trump administration has handed them a golden opportunity. MAGA is so fixated on ethnic cleansing that it is pulling Justice Department officials off crime-fighting to pursue immigration cases. A memo from acting Deputy Attorney General Emil Bove directed officers who had been working on transnational organized crime, money-laundering and major drug trafficking networks to focus instead on assisting ICE. Ditto for the FBI Joint Terrorism Task Forces. In fact, about 25% of FBI agents (and 40% in larger field offices) have been diverted from fighting financial crimes, public corruption, cybercrime and complex corporate investigations and pulled into immigration enforcement. Most maddening are the thousands of FBI and Homeland Security agents who've been pulled from investigations of child sex abuse to assist with deportations — as if the administration needed more ways of signaling that it's OK with child sex trafficking.</p><p>Democrats should stress that the funds appropriated for ICE would be far better deployed to local police departments. Bill Clinton's promise to hire 100,000 police officers was very popular in the '90s and cut against the Democrats' soft-on-crime image. The slogans write themselves: More Cops, Less ICE.</p><p>The voters are the last redoubt in the fight to reclaim American democracy and decency, and the Democratic Party, the world's oldest political party since the advent of universal suffrage, is the only entity that can carry the burden. If it can win a resounding victory in the House and Senate in nine months, there is hope for us.</p><p><i>Mona Charen is policy editor of The Bulwark and host of the “Beg to Differ” podcast.</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-6d0000" name="module-6d0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Send letters to <a class="Link" href="mailto:letters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >letters@suntimes.com</a>. More about <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/submitting-opinion-and-letters" >how to submit here</a>.</div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Mona Charen

entries.title: Don't lose sight of eye care during Low Vision Awareness Month
entries.summary: <p>This Saturday is Valentine's Day, and what better time to show that you "love your vision" than by getting a comprehensive eye exam to make sure that your eyes are and remain healthy.  After all, many diseases that can cause low vision can be managed if caught early.</p><p>The holiday also coincides with Low Vision Awareness Month, which we observe every February.  </p><p>In addition to prevention, this month also provides an opportunity for the public to increase its general knowledge about the causes of low vision and where to find help for any family members or friends who cope with it. </p><p>Receiving a low vision diagnosis is difficult and often scary for many patients. What do you do to make those who are newly diagnosed feel at ease and optimistic that they can continue to lead independent lives?</p><p>As an optometrist at The Chicago Lighthouse Low Vision Clinic, the oldest of its kind in the Midwest, I listen to our patients’ concerns, making it a point to know them on a personal level and hear how vision loss has impacted their activities at home, work, in retirement and school. Then I offer reassurances that while we might not be able to bring their vision back, we can find ways to help patients deal with their challenges. </p><p>Our clinic's comprehensive services and breadth of assistive technology ensure that we have solutions to offer. In addition, all our eye care providers have completed a low vision residency, ensuring that we have the most knowledgeable low vision care providers. </p><p>If you aren't easily able to access a low vision clinic, online resources can help guide you to  assistive devices and technologies that may help. <a class="Link" href="https://mytoolsforliving.com/" target="_blank" >Mytoolsforliving.com</a> is one such online  resource, that can help you find tools to assist in day-to-day activities if you have low vision. </p><p>Low Vision Awareness Month is also a time for thinking about inclusion. We often take for granted how much of our daily activities rely on good vision.</p><p>Reading packages, mail, emails, seeing faces, driving where we need to go. Think of the additional challenges posed by not having enough vision to do these things without adequate accommodations and accessibility.</p><p>We need to remember people with low vision when designing packaging, products and other items.</p><p>Inclusion of people with any disability is important, and Low Vision Awareness Month is a great  time to remind everyone about the power of inclusivity and accessibility for all, including those  living with low vision.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://chicagolighthouse.org/leadership/kara-h-crumbliss/" target="_blank" ><i>Kara Crumbliss</i></a><i>, chief, clinical services, The Chicago Lighthouse</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-ed0000" name="module-ed0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>Give us your take</h3><br>Send letters to the editor to <a class="Link" href="mailto:letters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >letters@suntimes.com</a>. To be considered for publication, letters must include your full name, your neighborhood or hometown and a phone number for verification purposes. Letters should be a maximum of approximately 375 words.</div> </div><p></p><h3>Name Washington team Jurgensen played for </h3><p>The Sun-Times recently published an Associated Press obituary for <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/nfl/2026/02/06/sonny-jurgensen-qb-dies-at-91-washington" >Sonny Jurgensen</a>, a Hall of Fame quarterback who spent 18 seasons in the NFL with the Philadelphia Eagles and Washington Redskins. However, only once, in a Jurgensen quote, was the Washington team referred to as the Redskins — the actual name of the team he spent 11 seasons with. The AP and Sun-Times are so obsessed with being "woke" and politically correct, the team was continually referred to in the story as "Washington." The team couldn't be referred to as the Commanders since Sonny never played for the Commanders. The team name was changed in 2022. You cannot rewrite history. Please be factual. He played for the Redskins.</p><p><i>Ray Miller, Olympia Fields</i><br></p>
entries.author: Letters to the Editor

entries.title: Dear Abby: Angry wife continues to wait for husband's apology
entries.summary: <p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> I have been married 50 years and recently remembered that my husband cheated on me with several different women. He admitted to one affair but swears he saw her only twice and they had sex only once. He says I'm imagining the other two. He hasn't apologized for the one he admitted to and refuses to discuss it or the other two, though I can see them in my mind's eye and feel it in my gut.</p><p>At this point, I'm more angry about his lying than I am about something that happened decades ago. Am I wrong to want the truth so I can get angry, deal with it and then forgive him? I also want a heartfelt apology. — <i>HEARTSICK IN TEXAS</i></p><p><b>DEAR HEARTSICK:</b> You do not need "the truth" so you can get angry. You are ALREADY as mad as heck. What you want is an apology from your cheating husband, and you aren't going to get it. Discussing this with a licensed marriage and family therapist may help you dissipate some of your anger and move on.</p><p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> Two of my mom's best friends ended their friendship with her after almost 50 years because of political differences. I grew up spending every holiday with these ladies and their families, in addition to summer lake and winter ski vacations and everything in between.</p><p>One of them is my godmother, and they both were like second moms to me. Can it be that simple to act as if they were never friends in the first place? Must Mom just accept the change, or can she try to repair the friendships? — <i>SAD SON IN CALIFORNIA</i></p><p><b>DEAR SON:</b> When political differences run so deep that close friendships are destroyed, I am sorry to say they are often not salvageable. I am not sure that time can heal the rift when someone is so entrenched in their political beliefs that they would jettison a 50-year friendship. Suggest to your mom that rather than look backward, she may try to cultivate friends who are less contentious.</p><p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> I am a 75-year-old therapist who was virtually a single parent. I still struggle with the guilt that I didn't do a good enough job with my three grown children, despite my trying with what energy and resources I continue to have. Their father has been pretty much absent since our divorce 35 years ago.</p><p>How can I get rid of the feeling that I am disrespected by my ungrateful adult children, and how do I stop trying to compensate them for their missing parent? There is minimal chance that they will change their attitude or beliefs at this point. — <i>STRUGGLING IN NEW JERSEY</i></p><p><b>DEAR STRUGGLING:</b> Thank you for asking. By now you must have realized that you can't buy love. As a psychotherapist, surely you are aware that therapists have therapists of their own (and many need this support). Because you are in pain over something you can't change by yourself, recognize that it's time to become proactive on your own behalf and consult one.</p><p><i>Dear Abby is written by Abigail Van Buren, also known as Jeanne Phillips, and was founded by her mother, Pauline Phillips. Contact Dear Abby at www.DearAbby.com or P.O. Box 69440, Los Angeles, CA 90069.</i></p><p>Good advice for everyone — teens to seniors — is in "The Anger in All of Us and How to Deal With It." To order, send your name and mailing address, plus check or money order for $8 (U.S. funds) to: Dear Abby, Anger Booklet, P.O. Box 446, Kings Mills, OH 45034-0446. (Shipping and handling are included in the price.)</p>
entries.author: Abigail Van Buren

entries.title: Longtime incumbent Preckwinkle faces stiff challenge from Ald. Reilly in Cook County board president primary
entries.summary: <p>Chicago Ald. Brendan Reilly, one of the most conservative members of the City Council, who bills himself as an independent voice, wants a new gig: to run Cook County government.</p><p>He’s looking to unseat longtime County Board President Toni Preckwinkle, who doubles as the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2024/03/14/toni-preckwinkle-political-muscle-democrats-march-primary-election" ><u>powerful leader</u> </a>of the Cook County Democratic Party, in the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2026/how-to-vote-illinois-primary" ><u>general primary</u> </a>on March 17, Preckwinkle’s 79th birthday.</p><p>She oversees one of the biggest counties in the U.S., including the county’s jail, vast court system and large public health system that has a mission to treat patients <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/politics/2025/05/23/how-medicaid-cuts-from-congress-could-affect-every-cook-county-resident" target="_blank" ><u>no matter if they can pay</u></a>. The county employs more than 20,000 people and has a roughly <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2025/11/20/cook-county-board-toni-preckwinkle-10-billion-2026-budget" target="_blank" ><u>$10 billion annual budget</u></a> that must be approved by a 17-member board of separately elected commissioners. Preckwinkle also oversees the <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/politics/2024/04/27/palos-preserves-gets-10-million-makeover" target="_blank" ><u>Forest Preserves</u></a> of Cook County.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-8e0000" name="image-8e0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/48521c8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7392x4149+0+391/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff3%2Fac%2Fc44b3d5b4d9894dcc51cdafbc2b5%2Fmayorbudget-101725-50.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bc1a541/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7392x4149+0+391/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff3%2Fac%2Fc44b3d5b4d9894dcc51cdafbc2b5%2Fmayorbudget-101725-50.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8864ddb/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7392x4149+0+391/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff3%2Fac%2Fc44b3d5b4d9894dcc51cdafbc2b5%2Fmayorbudget-101725-50.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Ald. Brendan Reilly (42nd) speaks with reporters after Mayor Brandon Johnson presented his proposed 2026 budget during a Chicago City Council meeting Oct. 16, 2025." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8864ddb/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7392x4149+0+391/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff3%2Fac%2Fc44b3d5b4d9894dcc51cdafbc2b5%2Fmayorbudget-101725-50.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/3bdf7cf/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7392x4149+0+391/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff3%2Fac%2Fc44b3d5b4d9894dcc51cdafbc2b5%2Fmayorbudget-101725-50.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8864ddb/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7392x4149+0+391/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff3%2Fac%2Fc44b3d5b4d9894dcc51cdafbc2b5%2Fmayorbudget-101725-50.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Ald. Brendan Reilly (42nd) speaks with reporters after Mayor Brandon Johnson presented his proposed 2026 budget during a Chicago City Council meeting Oct. 16, 2025.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Reilly, 54, who has represented downtown Chicago for roughly 19 years, is hammering Preckwinkle over a property tax system upgrade that, according to the Chicago Tribune and Injustice Watch, has been plagued by delays. Property tax bills have gone out late, causing school districts across the region to <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/education/2025/12/19/property-tax-payment-delay-costs-chicago-public-schools-almost-a-quarter-million-dollars-a-day" target="_blank" ><u>take out loans</u></a> with interest, as they waited to collect their share of property taxes.</p><p>“While my opponent has had a great career in public service, she’s stayed a bit too long,” Reilly said. “Cook County government is broken in a number of areas that are making it a lot less affordable to be able to live here.”</p><p>Reilly said he would terminate the county’s contract with Tyler Technologies, which has been working to upgrade the technology behind the property tax system for years, if needed.</p><p>Preckwinkle countered she’s one of several separately elected officials who oversee a complicated tax system. Other elected officials, such as the county assessor and treasurer, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2026/02/06/what-to-know-democratic-primary-cook-county-assessor-fritz-kaegi-pat-hynes" target="_blank" ><u>determine property values</u></a> and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2025/11/18/cook-county-treasurer-maria-pappas-mayoral-campaign-chicago-brandon-johnson" target="_blank" ><u>mail tax bills</u></a>.</p><p>“My view has been to try to get people to work together to solve the problems,” Preckwinkle said. “You can’t do that if you point fingers and throw people under the bus.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-9a0000" name="image-9a0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0dd08e9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6553x3678+0+347/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa7%2Fb8%2Fbd8f18ff4322a669b5ea9c3c0b4c%2Fmasstransit-121725-018.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/fe635ae/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6553x3678+0+347/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa7%2Fb8%2Fbd8f18ff4322a669b5ea9c3c0b4c%2Fmasstransit-121725-018.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8db14f5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6553x3678+0+347/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa7%2Fb8%2Fbd8f18ff4322a669b5ea9c3c0b4c%2Fmasstransit-121725-018.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Cook County Board President Toni Preckwinkle listens to Gov. JB Pritzker speak after signing the Northern Illinois Transit Authority Act during a ceremony at Union Station Dec. 16, 2025. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8db14f5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6553x3678+0+347/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa7%2Fb8%2Fbd8f18ff4322a669b5ea9c3c0b4c%2Fmasstransit-121725-018.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e51784a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6553x3678+0+347/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa7%2Fb8%2Fbd8f18ff4322a669b5ea9c3c0b4c%2Fmasstransit-121725-018.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8db14f5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6553x3678+0+347/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa7%2Fb8%2Fbd8f18ff4322a669b5ea9c3c0b4c%2Fmasstransit-121725-018.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Cook County Board President Toni Preckwinkle listens to Gov. JB Pritzker speak after signing the Northern Illinois Transit Authority Act during a ceremony at Union Station Dec. 16, 2025. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Candace Dane Chambers/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Preckwinkle is known for running a tight financial ship. She hasn’t raised the county’s portion of property taxes during her 16-year tenure, though a <a class="Link" href="https://news.wttw.com/2017/10/16/toni-preckwinkle-soda-tax-repeal-county-budget-shortfall" target="_blank" ><u>soda tax she supported years ago was repealed</u></a> after a huge backlash. The county’s pension fund is funded around 66%, <a class="Link" href="https://www.civicfed.org/dashboard/localgovtpensions" target="_blank" ><u>more than double</u></a> some of the city’s pension funds. The county has received four bond rating upgrades since 2021, while Chicago is mired in debt.</p><p>Preckwinkle underscores that <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2025/12/19/chicago-city-council-approves-alternate-revenue-plan-minus-mayor-brandon-johnsons-corporate-head-tax" target="_blank" ><u>Reilly and a group</u></a> of conservative and moderate alders recently muscled through a Chicago budget that includes a host of tax hikes, including a property tax increase for Chicago public libraries. While the budget avoided a new tax on the city’s largest corporations, <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/city-hall/2025/12/12/corporate-head-tax-brandon-johnson-2026-proposed-budget-job-killer-claim" target="_blank" ><u>detested by Chicago’s business community</u></a>, it “puts the burden entirely on taxpayers while exempting labor from any shared burden,” and included “only a handful of efficiencies and cost savings,” the Civic Federation, a non-partisan government watchdog, <a class="Link" href="https://civicfed.org/chicagos-fy2026-adopted-budget" target="_blank" ><u>wrote in an analysis</u></a>.</p><p>Roughly $5 billion of the city’s $16.6 billion budget this year will go toward pension and debt payments, after decades of mismanagement. That burden contributed to a nearly $1.2 billion gap between revenue and expenses in 2026, as the city has limited avenues to raise money aside from property tax and fee hikes.</p><p>Preckwinkle is a former history teacher and longtime Chicago alderperson representing the South Side before she was elected county board president in 2010. She uses her political power and progressive values to shape how the county spends money. She has championed <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/cook-county/2025/04/08/cook-county-leaders-are-touting-the-success-of-their-guaranteed-income-pilot-program" target="_blank" ><u>guaranteed income </u></a>for low to moderate income residents, <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/health-medicine/2025/06/05/cook-county-erases-nearly-665-million-in-medical-debt-for-more-than-a-half-million-residents" target="_blank" ><u>erased more than $600 million of medical debt</u></a>, and helped <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/the-end-of-cash-bail-in-illinois" target="_blank" ><u>eliminate cash bail</u></a> in Illinois. She has mentored many into higher office.</p><p>Reilly got his start in public service in the 1990s and worked as an aide to <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/politics/2025/02/13/what-former-illinois-house-speaker-michael-madigans-conviction-means-for-his-legacy" target="_blank" ><u>now-convicted </u></a>former Illinois House Speaker Michael Madigan. He left for the private sector and worked as an AT&T executive before defeating long-serving City Council incumbent, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2020/6/11/21288690/former-downtown-ald-burt-natarus-dies-council-obituary-carriages-valet-street-musicians" target="_blank" ><u>Burt Natarus</u></a>, in 2007.</p><p>Reilly hasn’t faced an opponent since. In 2020, he <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2020/10/27/21537277/alderman-brendan-reilly-states-attorney-kim-foxx-republican-pat-obrien-cook-county" target="_blank" ><u>broke with the Democratic Party</u></a> to endorse Republican Patrick O’Brien over Kim Foxx, Preckwinkle’s former chief of staff, for Cook County state’s attorney.</p><h3>Preckwinkle runs again because of Trump</h3><p>Preckwinkle said she was inspired to run for a fifth, four-year term to guard against Republican President Donald Trump. His One Big Beautiful Bill calls for <a class="Link" href="https://www.kff.org/medicaid/allocating-cbos-estimates-of-federal-medicaid-spending-reductions-across-the-states-enacted-reconciliation-package/" target="_blank" ><u>sweeping cuts</u></a> to public programs that support thousands of county residents, and <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/politics/2025/05/23/how-medicaid-cuts-from-congress-could-affect-every-cook-county-resident" target="_blank" ><u>could put a big dent</u></a> in the overall county budget.</p><p>As immigration agents detained people off the streets and fired <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/11/21/judge-hands-down-critical-review-of-federal-immigration-agents-unprecedented-use-of-force" target="_blank" ><u>pepper balls and tear gas</u></a> at protesters throughout Chicago and the suburbs, she issued an <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/10/16/preckwinkle-issues-executive-order-to-create-ice-free-zones-in-cook-county" target="_blank" ><u>executive order</u></a> to create “ICE-free zones” in Cook County.</p><p>“Trump’s declared war on us,” Preckwinkle said. “We need somebody who’s going to stand up to him and stand for our residents and the rule of law. He’s not that man,” she said of Reilly.</p><p>She points to his support for a measure aimed at creating carveouts in Chicago’s sanctuary law that prohibit police from helping with civil immigration enforcement. Reilly was one of 11 Council members who pushed for a vote on the now-stalled measure, after a chorus of advocacy organizations <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/city-hall/2025/01/10/donald-trump-deportation-plan-ice-immigration-advocates-chicago-police" target="_blank" ><u>warned it</u></a> would open the door to constitutional rights violations and legal challenges.</p><p>In a statement, Reilly said he supports abolishing U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement and returning the agency to its “core functions during the Obama administration.” He said he would defend the <a class="Link" href="https://www.cookcountyil.gov/news/president-preckwinkle-signs-executive-order-banning-use-cook-county-owned-property-and" target="_blank" ><u>county’s restrictions</u></a> on using local resources for certain federal immigration enforcement. But he supports carveouts for people arrested or convicted for felonies such as sex crimes involving children or gang-related violence.</p><p>One of the biggest challenges the county faces is bracing for an estimated almost $300 million in losses per year, largely due to people losing their health insurance. Low-income residents who have public Medicaid health insurance will have <a class="Link" href="https://hfs.illinois.gov/info/fedresctr/medicaidfedpolicychfs.html" target="_blank" ><u>new work requirements</u></a> next year and more frequent checks to make sure they qualify, while others might drop insurance they bought on the government exchanges because <a class="Link" href="https://www.pbs.org/newshour/health/health-subsidies-expire-launching-millions-of-americans-into-2026-with-steep-insurance-hikes" target="_blank" ><u>subsidies are gone</u></a>.</p><p>People might still show up for medical care at Cook County Health’s two hospitals and several clinics, but might not be able to afford to pay what could be big bills. That means less money flowing to the county. The majority of the county’s patients have Medicaid or no insurance, records show. Dr. Erik Mikaitis, CEO of CCH, said the amount of uninsured patients is already swelling.</p><p>Reilly said the county should have planned for Medicaid losses earlier.</p><p>“You don’t wait for federal cuts to happen,” Reilly said. “You build a firewall before they hit.”</p><p>County leaders say they have been preparing. The health system started tightening its belt last year, with 10% cuts across all departments that will continue through 2026. They froze about 200 vacant positions. The county has set aside around $320 million in reserves, partly in case federal grants for everything from transportation to public health get cut, and nearly $70 million for potential Medicaid losses, a county spokesman said.</p><p>Reilly suggests pre-ranking medical services to keep or cut, prioritizing the ER and trauma care. He declined to say what he would cut, deferring to the health system.</p><p>Mikaitis said there are contingency plans — not cutting services but potentially consolidating them, such as offering a service in three clinics instead of five.</p><h3>Reilly suggests a Cook County ID</h3><p>In a statement, Reilly said he wants to make sure “Cook County services are for Cook County residents,” and that the county isn’t absorbing costs from other counties. He points to <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/politics/2020/03/12/treating-uninsured-patients-is-wreaking-havoc-on-cook-county-finances" target="_blank" ><u>WBEZ reporting</u></a> that underscores the impact on county finances for providing the most charity care, or discounted care, of any hospital in Illinois — around $217 million at the county’s John H. Stroger Jr. Hospital in 2024, a WBEZ analysis of the most recent <a class="Link" href="https://hfsrb.illinois.gov/inventories-data.html" target="_blank" ><u>state records</u></a> shows. In some cases, private hospitals stabilize patients, then refer them to the county for follow-up care.</p><p>“Verified residency and referral data would allow the county and the Attorney General to audit community benefit reports, enforce state discount laws, and hold private systems accountable when costs are shifted onto the public safety net,” Reilly said.</p><p>A health system spokeswoman said only about 4% of patients live outside the county. The county’s financial assistance program, CareLink, is only for county residents, and <a class="Link" href="https://healthcarereportcard.illinois.gov/hospital-uninsured-patient-discount-act" target="_blank" ><u>an Illinois law</u></a> caps how much any hospital can collect from uninsured patients who live in the state. Patients who live outside of Illinois and pay out of pocket could qualify for a discount.</p><p>Reilly said a countywide ID, which county commissioners have <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2017/7/5/18342498/two-cook-county-commissioners-proposing-county-i-d-card" target="_blank" ><u>floated before</u></a>, would help people prove residency for county services, such as medical care. The idea is not to restrict care or duplicate existing ID programs, like Chicago’s CityKey, Reilly said. The county ID would be for suburban residents, he suggests.</p><p>Whoever wins the Democratic primary would likely win in the November general election. There is <a class="Link" href="https://www.cookcountyclerkil.gov/elections/results-and-election-data/election-results/candidate-filing" target="_blank" ><u>no Republican candidate</u></a> for county board president. Michael Murphy is running as a Libertarian. Preckwinkle last won with about 69% of the vote in 2022 against Bob Fioretti.</p><p>Should she win, Preckwinkle said it would be her last term as county board president. She said she also plans to run for just one more, two-year term this spring to lead the Democratic Party.</p><p><i>Kristen Schorsch and Mariah Woelfel cover government for WBEZ. </i><br></p>
entries.author: Mariah Woelfel | WBEZ

entries.title: Model shop that provided the first draft of many great Chicago buildings closes
entries.summary: <p>For 35 years, Columbian Model & Exhibit Works has given the city glimpses of the future.</p><p>The River West company designed and built architectural models for developers and architects that provided an advance look — often with astonishing accuracy and detail — of the buildings, neighborhoods, skyscrapers and places planned for the city.</p><p>Their vast catalog includes models of the Lakeshore East high-rise development, along the south edge of Wacker Drive just west of DuSable Lake Shore Drive; the Jeanne Gang-designed St. Regis tower, at 363 E. Wacker Drive; and the huge 1/16th depiction of the 20-acre Obama Presidential Center campus.</p><p>But that all came to an end this month when the venerable company shut its doors for good.</p><p>Columbian Model President Catherine Tinker decided at the beginning of the year to retire. And she said her partners didn't want to continue the company, fearful that technological advancements in creating virtual models would ultimately eat away their business.</p><p>"They are concerned that because of the digital revolution, there's not enough work or physical models anymore," she said. "It's difficult. We're cleaning out the shop. It's difficult."</p><h3>From attorney to model-maker</h3><p>In the city of "no little plans," physical architectural models were once a big thing. </p><p>Former Mayor Richard J. Daley, attempting to show progress, would hold news conferences standing before impressive scale models of a proposed central area with new high-rises and development from 18th Street to North Avenue.</p><p>Over the decades, the models were our first look at many well-known projects around town from Crown Hall at the Illinois Institute of Technology, Marina City, Sears Tower, Central Station, the Harold Washington Library entries, Millennium Park and more.</p><p>That's less so now. </p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-250000" name="image-250000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Former President Barack Obama examines a model of the Obama Presidential Center campus made by Columbian Model & Exhibit Works.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Provided by the Obama Foundation</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>In addition to tech advancements, Tinker said a tepid Chicago real estate market has caused fewer developers to pay for large models needed to attract buyers and investors.</p><p>Model making is also exacting work that requires materials and textures that can mimic the look of steel, brick and stone, while working with an architect to get the scale, color and details just right.</p><p>"It has to tell the story that the developer or [whomever] is trying to tell," Columbian Model Senior Designer Bill Bauman said. "But it's at a smaller scale, so the detail has to be finessed. So that you still get the idea without making it identical to full size."</p><p>It's a line of work Tinker fell into by chance 35 years ago.</p><p>A former trial attorney, she got introduced to model making when she got legal exhibits made for court cases.</p><p>She represented Morton Thiokol in a case against the NASA contractor, following the 1986 Space Shuttle Challenger tragedy. That's when the spacecraft exploded 73 seconds after liftoff when its rocket booster O-rings failed. The shuttle's seven crew members were killed.</p><p>"We actually got little models of the O-ring made that we shipped over to England so that we could explain the case to the guys from Lloyd's [of London insurance company] because they were the ones that ultimately were paying for everything," Tinker said.</p><p>Tinker said she turned to the model-making business after getting "burned out" with the legal profession — despite having no experience fabricating the objects.</p><p>"Originally, I was going to make trial exhibits," she said. "But then the architectural model-making part just sort of grew organically. So we ended up being architectural scale model makers."</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item"> <bsp-carousel class="Carousel Enhancement" data-align-center> <a 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/38b428c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2000x2000+474+0/resize/600x600!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F98%2F6f%2F3b68733d4759b2be415e10991665%2Fmodel-260211-51.jpg data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/be11fee/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2000x2000+474+0/resize/300x300!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F98%2F6f%2F3b68733d4759b2be415e10991665%2Fmodel-260211-51.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIzMDBweCIgd2lkdGg9IjMwMHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> </span> </div> </div> </div></div><div class="FlickityCustomNavigation-wrapper"> <div class="FlickityCustomNavigation below"> <button class="FlickityCustomNavigation-button-prev" type="button" aria-label="Previous"> <svg class="FlickityCustomNavigation-button-icon"><use xlink:href="#icon-left"></use></svg> </button> <button class="FlickityCustomNavigation-button-next" type="button" aria-label="Next"> <svg class="FlickityCustomNavigation-button-icon"><use xlink:href="#icon-right"></use></svg> </button> </div> </div></div> </bsp-carousel> </div> </div><p></p><h3>A ‘sad’ end</h3><p>The Obama Presidential Center model is on display at the Obama Foundation headquarters. The work was widely shown and broadcast before the actual campus, scheduled to open in the spring, took shape.</p><p>"We were very disappointed that we never got to meet the Obamas," Tinker said. "I really thought they might come over [to the office] but they didn't."</p><p>Columbian Model's work also includes the Chicago Architecture Center's huge — 320 square feet — Chicago Model built in 2009.</p><p>The work shows 400 blocks of the city and downtown and is detailed with more than 1,000 buildings. It's updated every few months by Columbian Model.</p><p>Chicago Architecture Center Chief Marketing Officer Lauren Bakos said, "It made me sad," when she heard the shop was closing.</p><p>"I understand that technology has made it easier to do things digitally and use augmented reality and all of that," she said. "But to show off these structures that are being developed in Chicago, I think it's a really beautiful art. And it's sad that it's kind of a dying one."</p><p>Bakos said the company left the CAC with a few models to plug into the big exhibit, including one of the revamped Thompson Center.</p><p>"So we're on the hunt for someone else who can take over that project," she said.</p><p>And Columbian Model is looking for a new home for all its work. Bauman said the company has thrown away some of its models, including a few of the Lakeshore East towers.</p><p>"We've lost a lot them, but we still we have a dozen or so," Bauman said.</p><p>Tinker said, "There are smaller models that were on shelves that I need find to homes find for."</p>
entries.author: Lee Bey

entries.title: Need more 'Heated Rivalry'? Read these sexy sports romances by Chicago authors
entries.summary: <p>Three weeks before the “Heated Rivalry” sports romance premiered on HBO Max and<b> </b>generated breathless buzz worldwide, K.C. Carmichael published her second novel, “The Kennedy Rule.”</p><p>It just so happens to follow two professional male athletes.</p><p>Who play on rival hockey teams<i>.</i></p><p>And fall in love.</p><p>Unintentionally following the same beats as a hit TV show has yielded a boost in book sales for the Chicago author.</p><p>“It has been a wonderful surprise,” said Carmichael, of Austin, who is a former figure skater and self-described “hopeless romantic.”</p><p>“My publisher and I knew that ‘The Kennedy Rule’ was special. We knew that it was going to really touch a lot of readers, but thanks to ‘Heated Rivalry,’ it has brought more readers to the book that much faster.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-920000" name="image-920000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/dba7163/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff8%2F56%2F0b27891b40f09bdc76f4a29a116d%2Fromancenovels-260214-06.jpg width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5b2411f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff8%2F56%2F0b27891b40f09bdc76f4a29a116d%2Fromancenovels-260214-06.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="ROMANCENOVELS_260214-06.jpg" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5b2411f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff8%2F56%2F0b27891b40f09bdc76f4a29a116d%2Fromancenovels-260214-06.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5dbd3eb/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff8%2F56%2F0b27891b40f09bdc76f4a29a116d%2Fromancenovels-260214-06.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5b2411f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff8%2F56%2F0b27891b40f09bdc76f4a29a116d%2Fromancenovels-260214-06.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>“The Kennedy Rule,” by K.C. Carmichael, has been compared to hit HBO Max TV show “Heated Rivalry.”</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Giacomo Cain/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Based on the “Game Changers” novel series by Rachel Reid, "Heated Rivalry” takes place in Canada, while “The Kennedy Rule” (Storm Publishing)<b> </b>focuses on U.S. players during the Winter Olympics. </p><p>There is growing demand for such sports romances, and Chicago, home to several iconic professional teams, is producing an increasing number of authors willing to write them. Novelists are writing everything from hot hockey stories to steamy football fantasies. Enthusiasm is even spilling over into real life, with <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/entertainment-and-culture/2023/11/13/23953363/last-chapter-book-shop-chicago-romance-novels-bookstore-roscoe-village" target="_blank" >The Last Chapter Book Shop</a> in Roscoe Village organizing a romance novelist meet-and-greet paired with an outing to a Blackhawks game next month.</p><p>“I'm glad that this genre is getting its moment in the sun,” Carmichael said.</p><p>Bellwood writer Nicole Falls, who centers Black characters in her books, said fans of the genre enjoy the high stakes involved in both sports and love.</p><p>“There are obstacles that you have to surpass for each," said Falls, whose catalog features two sports romance series, "Nymphs & Trojans" and "New Beginnings."</p><p>"You're communicating when things are good and bad. The best relationships are based on very good communication.”</p><h3>A genre pioneer creates a fictional Chicago NFL team </h3><h3></h3><p>The momentum around sports romance started to build decades ago, according to Phillips, who is recognized as a pioneer of the genre. In 1994, she launched her “Chicago Stars” series, named for a fictional professional football team whose players, coaches and staffers — and the people they love — have fueled 11 books. The latest, “And the Crowd Went Wild" (HarperCollins), was released on Feb. 10. It follows a former Hollywood star and a hotshot quarterback who rekindle their romance in an old railcar in the woods.</p><p>Phillips said readers will be drawn in by the “snarky, fun dialogue” and ups and downs of the story.</p><p>“I love a book where readers are going to laugh and then they're going to get tears in their eyes,” she said. “We've got two lost people who need each other very much, but they're not going to show it. And we also have a dog. It's always good to have a dog.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-580000" name="image-580000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f96a063/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3150x1768+0+1482/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F6e%2Fa5%2Fda4f864e47dab217fd26c8215859%2Fsep-author-photo-credit-chandra-wicke-photography.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1b7f4a2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3150x1768+0+1482/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F6e%2Fa5%2Fda4f864e47dab217fd26c8215859%2Fsep-author-photo-credit-chandra-wicke-photography.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/72519c6/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3150x1768+0+1482/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F6e%2Fa5%2Fda4f864e47dab217fd26c8215859%2Fsep-author-photo-credit-chandra-wicke-photography.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="SEP author photo - credit Chandra Wicke Photography.jpg" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/72519c6/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3150x1768+0+1482/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F6e%2Fa5%2Fda4f864e47dab217fd26c8215859%2Fsep-author-photo-credit-chandra-wicke-photography.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/086902e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3150x1768+0+1482/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F6e%2Fa5%2Fda4f864e47dab217fd26c8215859%2Fsep-author-photo-credit-chandra-wicke-photography.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/72519c6/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3150x1768+0+1482/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F6e%2Fa5%2Fda4f864e47dab217fd26c8215859%2Fsep-author-photo-credit-chandra-wicke-photography.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>A pioneer in the sports romance genre, Naperville author Susan Elizabeth Phillips has written 11 books in the “Chicago Stars” series. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Chandra Wicke Photography</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Phillips' readers have also become engaged in the saga of the Chicago Stars. In the books, the author writes them as crosstown rivals of the Chicago Bears.</p><p>“My Stars have won either four or five Super Bowls, and the Bears have only won one,” she said. “My Stars are in a bit of a slump right now, but they'll recover. They always do.”</p><p>Phillips has been inspiring other writers to create their own sports-based love stories since she published the first "Chicago Stars" novel.</p><p>“Within the next few years, I remember seeing a baseball book and another football book, and it just kept progressing,” she said. “In the last 10 years, we've had wrestling and roller derby and a bunch of hockey books long before ‘Heated Rivalry.’ Sports romance has been going strong for a long time.”</p><h3>Supercharging the queer romance space </h3><p>But the steamy "Heated Rivalry" series will, no doubt, bolster the market for romance novels, said Jen Prokop, of Hyde Park, who co-hosts the "<a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/books/2024/11/18/romance-books-best-2024-fated-mates-podcast-chicago-bookstores" target="_blank" >Fated Mates</a>" romance novel podcast.</p><p>“Hopefully it will also supercharge the queer romance space,” she said.</p><p>In the past, queer romances in media often ended in death or some other form of tragedy, Prokop said. Bucking that trend is part of why "Heated Rivalry" was so successful. </p><p>“Embracing the radical idea that queer people deserve to find happiness and joy and love, and that that can be publicly celebrated, is the story of ‘Heated Rivalry,'" she said. </p><p>"It’s also what romance does best. It shows that you don't have to have a perfect life. Society doesn't have to be perfect. But people are going to fall in love and try to create happiness together.”</p><p>By writing "The Kennedy Rule" and planning more books in the series, K.C. Carmichael is helping to fill those gaps. She also published another LGBTQ+ romance, "300 New Year's Eves" (Rising Action) in December.</p><p>“I used to be a fantasy and dystopian reader, but that got to be really heavy,” Carmichael said. “Eventually romance caught me because it's fun. There's so much more room to play." </p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-ca0000" name="image-ca0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f2effe9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F15%2F18%2F1b4fe6244d20a48b4ec490656f2c%2Fromancenovels-260214-04.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/fee028e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F15%2F18%2F1b4fe6244d20a48b4ec490656f2c%2Fromancenovels-260214-04.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/26fac34/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F15%2F18%2F1b4fe6244d20a48b4ec490656f2c%2Fromancenovels-260214-04.jpg" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/26fac34/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F15%2F18%2F1b4fe6244d20a48b4ec490656f2c%2Fromancenovels-260214-04.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5f1a7c4/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F15%2F18%2F1b4fe6244d20a48b4ec490656f2c%2Fromancenovels-260214-04.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/26fac34/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F15%2F18%2F1b4fe6244d20a48b4ec490656f2c%2Fromancenovels-260214-04.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>K.C. Carmichael, author of “The Kennedy Rule,” skates on the ice at Fifth Third Arena on Wednesday, Feb. 11, 2026.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Giacomo Cain/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Those asking for more diversity in the romance genre include Falls. Her "Nymphs & Trojans" series, co-written with Alexandra Warren, follows characters on fictional WNBA and NBA teams in Nashville. Her "New Beginnings" series focuses on Black women playing baseball, soccer and golf.</p><p>Falls said it's important for her to portray Black love in a positive light.</p><p>“It is what I want to put on a pedestal, because a lot of media portrays broken images of Black people,” she said.<b> </b></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-420000" name="image-420000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a4a7dce/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2316x1300+0+894/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F3e%2F3a%2F00bc49784d2ba493403894f533b5%2Fnf-headshot.png 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/99a860f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2316x1300+0+894/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F3e%2F3a%2F00bc49784d2ba493403894f533b5%2Fnf-headshot.png
