class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Bellwood author Nicole Falls centers Black characters in her sports romance books, which are part of the “Nymphs & Trojans” series, co-written with Alexandra Warren, and the “New Beginnings” series.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Courtesy of Nicole Falls</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>And because the romance genre requires writers to pen happy endings, readers find comfort in their stories, Falls said.</p><p>“With everything that's happening in the world right now, people are just clinging to a little piece of something positive,” she said. “Sometimes you just need to escape into something that makes you feel good in order to forget everything else.”</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-ee0000" name="module-ee0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3><b>Steamy Chicago sports novels and where to find them </b></h3><br><b>“The Kennedy Rule” by K.C. Carmichael </b><br>Carmichael’s new book focuses on a budding romance between two rival U.S. hockey players during the Winter Olympics.<br><br><b>The “Nymphs & Trojans” series by Nicole Falls and Alexandra Warren</b><br>This four-book series follows fictional WNBA and NBA teams in Nashville.<br><br><b>The “Chicago Stars” series by Susan Elizabeth Phillips</b><br>Phillips series of 11 books is named for a fictional professional football team. The latest book, “And the Crowd Went Wild,” follows a former Hollywood star and a hotshot quarterback who rekindle their romance.<br><hr><h3>Local independent romance bookshops</h3><br><b>The Last Chapter Book Shop</b><br>2013 W. Roscoe St.<br><br><b>Partners in Crime (opening Feb. 21)</b><br>4105 N. Lincoln Ave.<br><br><b>Love’s Sweet Arrow</b><br>17200 Oak Park Ave., Suite 103, Tinley Park<br><br><b>Pink Couch Books</b><br>1161 Wilmette Ave., Wilmette</div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Erica Thompson

entries.title: Grocery prices in Chicago have climbed double digits over the last year. Here's how we know
entries.summary: <p>It’s been more than a year since the Chicago Sun-Times started tracking the monthly price of 35 common grocery items at Jewel-Osco, Mariano's, Target and Walmart.</p><p>The verdict? What went up, mostly didn’t come down.</p><p>At Chicago’s largest grocery chain Jewel-Osco, 18 items went up in price, 15 stayed the same and two — Land O’ Lakes butter and Doritos nacho cheese chips — dropped by 50 cents and 80 cents, respectively, over the past 13 months.</p><p>With most items going up in price, it meant our shopping cart at Jewel went up by a total of $21.80 — from $263.15 on Jan. 7, 2025, to $284.95 on Feb. 3, 2026.</p><p>President Donald Trump famously said during his 2024 campaign he’d get prices down “starting on Day One” of his presidency. And high grocery prices played an out-sized role in the presidential election, with many voters saying they were “very concerned” about food costs, according to a 2024 survey by the Associated Press.</p><p>Edgewater resident Lena Howard, 30, said she doesn’t need hard data to know that groceries are expensive.</p><p>“Everything is expensive — the milk, the eggs, the cereal,” Howard, a mother of two boys, aged 10 and 8, said as she loaded groceries into her car at a North Side Jewel. “For a box of cereal, they want damn near $10.”</p><p>Howard said she spends about $250 a week on food and household items. To stretch her budget, she cooks at home, except on Fridays, and makes big batches of spaghetti and chicken Alfredo that can be repurposed for lunches or kept in the freezer.</p><p>She usually shops at Jewel because it’s close to her home but sometimes she makes the half-hour drive to a Walmart in Skokie, where prices are lower.</p><p>At Walmart, many of the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2025/07/18/supermarket-super-pain-trump-campaign-food-prices-inflation-tariffs" >35 items on our list</a> dropped in price more often than they rose, compared to one year ago. Seventeen items went down totaling $9.60 in savings, seven items increased totaling $5.81, seven stayed the same and four didn’t have enough data to be tracked.</p><p>The prices of our items at Mariano’s and Target mostly increased or stayed flat. A grand total for the baskets couldn’t be made because not every item was available each month.</p><p>At Mariano’s, 14 items stayed the same in price, 13 went up, six went down and two did not have enough data. At Target, 19 items went up, 10 went down, five stayed the same and one didn’t have enough data.</p><p>Grocery expert Phil Lempert, known as the “Supermarket Guru,” said the truth is price increases that slammed consumers beginning in mid-2022 are mostly not going away.</p><p>Climate change is affecting crops and cattle, tariffs are hitting imports and messing up farming forecasts and immigration enforcement is impacting labor, Lempert said. And the large publicly-owned food and consumer product companies are under pressure to deliver growth for their stockholders.</p><p>“It puts the consumer in a really difficult position because there’s not a lot we can do,” Lempert said.</p><p>Jewel and Mariano’s, as well as their parent companies Albertsons and Kroger, respectively, didn’t respond to requests for comment. A Target spokeswoman declined to comment.</p><p>Some of the products whose prices rose from January 2025 to February 2026 include:<br></p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" id="rte-f7a844a2-084d-11f1-99ee-413f9fa0de1f"><li><b>Folgers ground coffee:</b> Jumped in price at all four stores. At Jewel and Mariano’s, prices rose 38.5%, from $6.49 in January 2025 to $8.99 in February 2026. At Target, it increased from $6.29 to $8.49, up 35%, and at Walmart, the price increased 20.6%,from $5.78 to $6.97. Coffee prices are up nationwide due to poor harvests globally, as well as lingering effects from tariffs.</li><li><b>Nathan’s Famous bun-length hot dogs:</b> Increased in price at all four stores. At Jewel, the price climbed from $6.49 to $8.49, a 30.8% increase. The price at Mariano’s went from $6.49 to $7.99.</li><li><b>Ground beef:</b> Over the past year, prices rose 25% at Jewel and Walmart. Price increases nationwide are blamed on drought, smaller herd sizes and increased costs for cattle feed.</li><li><b>M&M’s peanut candy:</b> An 18.08-ounce bag cost more at Jewel, Mariano’s and Target, with the price at Jewel hitting a whopping $13.99, up 27.3% from $10.99 in January 2025.</li><li><b>Oreo:</b> Prices for an 18.12-ounce package also increased at Jewel, Mariano’s and Target. It reached $7.49 this month at Jewel, up from $6.99 in January 2025. At Mariano’s, it was $7.39, up from $6.49.</li><li><b>Coke:</b> A 12-pack cost more at all four stores. The price was $9.99 in January 2025 at Jewel and Mariano’s, and increased 20% to $11.99 this month.</li><li><b>Always:</b> A package of the feminine product rose at all four stores. At Jewel, a 46-count box jumped from $9.49 in January 2025 to $11.99 this month, a 26.3% increase.</li><li><b>Pampers Swaddlers:</b> A box of 84 size 2 diapers went up Jewel, Mariano’s and Target, with the biggest increase at Mariano’s, up 9.4% from $31.99 to $34.99.</li></ul><p>Egg prices hit a breaking point for many consumers early last year, when avian flu decimated farms and caused prices to skyrocket. </p><p>The Sun-Times tracked Eggland's Best grade-A large white eggs, as well as individual store brands and recorded a peak in March 2025, when a dozen eggs of Eggland’s Best hit $9.49 at Mariano’s.</p><p>Those super-high prices have largely dropped now that the bird flu crisis is less of a threat.</p><p>This month, Eggland’s Best eggs were $5.99 at Jewel; $5.49 at Mariano’s for a dozen large eggs; and $3.96 for extra-large eggs at Walmart.</p><p>Store brand eggs were as low as $1.99 at Target and $1.97 at Walmart.</p><h3>Shrinkflation’s double-whammy</h3><p>Tide original liquid laundry detergent rose in price at two of the four stores we checked. It also shrunk in size by 4 ounces over the course of 13 months to 80 ounces.</p><p>Henry Molski, spokesperson for Procter & Gamble, manufacturer of Tide, said the amount is less but the detergent is still able to clean the same 64 loads of laundry advertised on the label — assuming loads of 6 pounds — because it was reformulated at a higher concentration.</p><p>“Tide continues to concentrate to provide a superior cleaning experience. In fact, Tide made its biggest upgrade in liquid in over 20 years with the Tide boosted formula in the fall of ‘25,” Molski said.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-e60000" name="image-e60000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/31a415e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6547x3674+0+139/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F31%2F97%2Fb79ae05f4734b9868a53c1ad91bb%2Ftide-comp.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d48b9d7/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6547x3674+0+139/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F31%2F97%2Fb79ae05f4734b9868a53c1ad91bb%2Ftide-comp.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/835b711/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6547x3674+0+139/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F31%2F97%2Fb79ae05f4734b9868a53c1ad91bb%2Ftide-comp.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Two bottles of Tide laundry detergent next to each other" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/835b711/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6547x3674+0+139/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F31%2F97%2Fb79ae05f4734b9868a53c1ad91bb%2Ftide-comp.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7a98149/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6547x3674+0+139/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F31%2F97%2Fb79ae05f4734b9868a53c1ad91bb%2Ftide-comp.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/835b711/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6547x3674+0+139/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F31%2F97%2Fb79ae05f4734b9868a53c1ad91bb%2Ftide-comp.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Tide liquid laundry detergent shrunk in volume from 84 ounces (left) to 80 ounces.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Sun-Times file</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Tide was $14.99 at Jewel in January 2025, and it's now $15.99. At Target, it went from $12.99 for an 84-ounce bottle to $13.69 for 80 ounces.</p><p>Edgar Dworsky, founder of <a class="Link" href="https://www.consumerworld.org/" target="_blank" >ConsumerWorld.org</a> and a former assistant attorney general for Massachusetts, was one of the first to spot the smaller size of Tide and said many consumers won’t realize they need to use less detergent per load to get the same 64 loads.</p><p>He said shrinking products pop up everywhere from toilet paper rolls, with a few less sheets, to a cereal box that stays the same height but gets narrower and bottles that get tapered or dimpled so they hold less liquid.</p><div class="ActionBox Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="ActionBox-content"> <div class="ActionBox-title">What are you seeing at the grocery store? </div> <div class="ActionBox-description">Tell your story to reporter Stephanie Zimmermann.</div> </div> <div class="ActionBox-cta"> <a class="Button" href="mailto:szimmermann@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >Email me</a> </div> </div><p>When the price stays the same on a shrinking product, the consumer loses money. When the price increases on a smaller version, it’s a double-whammy.</p><p>Shrinking products were more prevalent a few years ago, when inflation was higher, Dworsky said. Inflation peaked at 9.1% in June 2022, as the world emerged from the COVID-19 pandemic.</p><p>“Shrinkflation, downsizing has been around forever, and it’s not going anywhere, but we see it in waves,” he said. “At the moment, it’s fairly even.”</p><p>Consumers can guard against <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/consumer-affairs/2025/11/15/paying-more-smaller-restaurant-grocery-portions-shrinkflation" >shrinkflation</a> by paying attention to what's in the package, whether it's by weight or by count, of the products they regularly purchase, Dworsky said.</p><p>Because he tracks the prices of items he regularly buys, it helps him recognize when a sale is worth it. </p><p>“When you recognize a good deal, load up on that item,” he said.</p><h3>Tracking sales</h3><p>The Sun-Times tracked shelf prices, but also the sale prices when the deal was for a single item that didn’t require a mobile app or loyalty program.</p><p>Some sales were significant. For example, those eye-popping $13.99 bag of peanut M&M’s at Jewel were on sale in February for $8.99 — no coupon required.</p><p>But with some items we followed, the cost climbed so high that the promotional price exceeded the old shelf price.</p><p>For example, a 1-pound package of 85% lean ground beef at Jewel was on sale for $6.99 this month, $1 more than the shelf price from January 2025. The sale price this month for Folgers coffee was $8.49, which was $2 more than its shelf price of $6.49 in January 2025. We also saw this trend with Oreo cookies, Tropicana orange juice and Always pads.</p><p>A New York Times/Siena poll released last month found that while a majority of Americans said they’re able to afford basics like rent, gas and groceries, close to 60% are concerned about rising costs and only 14% said they’re able to get ahead financially.</p><p>Art Friedson, of Lake View, caught a glimpse of consumers' anxiety in November. While in line at the supermarket, he saw an older couple and an “unbelievably patient” cashier spend several minutes leafing through the store’s flyer and checking its mobile app to find a coupon for one of the handful of items they were purchasing.</p><p>The couple's grand total was only $7.01. “You don’t do that unless you really, really need those extra couple of pennies,” Friedson said. “That’s how things are in a supermarket these days. It’s heartbreaking.”</p><p>Many consumers treat sales and coupons as an integral part of their shopping.</p><p>Daniel Serafini, of Grayslake, said he won’t set foot in Jewel without checking the store’s ads and downloading digital coupons off Jewel’s mobile app.</p><p>The retired computer programmer said he’s found some decent deals, like four boxes of cereal for $8, though he always checks his receipt to make sure the digital coupons were applied and tells customer service if they weren’t.</p><p>But his real savings strategy is going to Woodman’s Markets, where the prices are often lower. He’ll also go to Menards, which despite being known for selling home improvement and hardware items also stocks many grocery products.</p><p>At Menards, Serafini shops during the store’s rebate periods then mails his receipts to get an in-store rebate coupon, equal to 11% of what he spent. He then uses those coupons to buy more items on his shopping list. He recently got close to $40 in free groceries.</p><p>“It’s worth it,” Serafini said. ”To me, it’s a no brainer.”</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-480000" name="module-480000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>Ways to save</h3><ul id="rte-67c528e2-0856-11f1-8b6f-937da1d85873"><li>Plan ahead by creating weekly meal plans and batch-cook foods that can be frozen or eaten as leftovers and lunches.</li><li>Always shop with a list.</li><li>Check for store sales in advance. If your go-to store has an app, consider downloading it to clip digital coupons.</li><li>Stock up, if you can, when sales are good. But if you see a sale that requires you to buy multiples of a product, compare the unit price to make sure it’s truly a great deal.</li><li>Choose a store’s private label brand, which is often just as good as the brand-name product but often 25% cheaper. Aldi and Trader Joe’s are two grocers known for selling products under their own brands at lower prices.</li><li>Eat less meat and add more beans, lentils and other legumes to your diet.</li></ul></div> </div><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-af0000" name="module-af0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-6a0000" name="image-6a0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/53508ee/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4041x2268+0+322/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe3%2F40%2Fe59d81cb473bb5b2682b884f349d%2Fgroceryprices-all-groceries-v1.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/3bae980/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4041x2268+0+322/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe3%2F40%2Fe59d81cb473bb5b2682b884f349d%2Fgroceryprices-all-groceries-v1.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bb88bd2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4041x2268+0+322/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe3%2F40%2Fe59d81cb473bb5b2682b884f349d%2Fgroceryprices-all-groceries-v1.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Grocery items that the Sun-Times has tracked." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bb88bd2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4041x2268+0+322/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe3%2F40%2Fe59d81cb473bb5b2682b884f349d%2Fgroceryprices-all-groceries-v1.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/68432b5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4041x2268+0+322/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe3%2F40%2Fe59d81cb473bb5b2682b884f349d%2Fgroceryprices-all-groceries-v1.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bb88bd2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4041x2268+0+322/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe3%2F40%2Fe59d81cb473bb5b2682b884f349d%2Fgroceryprices-all-groceries-v1.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Grocery items that the Sun-Times has tracked.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Brian Ernst/Sun-Times file</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><h3>How we’re tracking grocery prices</h3><br>The Chicago Sun-Times has been tracking the shelf and sale prices for 35 items, from staples like milk, bread and eggs to fresh produce, meats and frozen food as well as coffee, cookies and candy. We’ve also tracked products like shampoo, diapers, detergent and toilet paper.<br><br>We decided to choose packaged items from well-known manufacturers such as Procter & Gamble, Kraft Heinz, Tyson Foods, Hormel, Smithfield Foods, Nestle, Mars, Mondelez, Coca-Cola, PepsiCo, General Mills and Unilever.<br><br>Prices skyrocketed in mid-2022, under former President Joe Biden’s administration and following the COVID-19 pandemic. The high cost of groceries played a large role in the 2024 presidential campaign, in which then-candidate Donald Trump repeatedly promised to lower grocery prices.<br><br>Our price data is from the first Tuesday of each month and was tracked in person and online at Jewel, as well as online at Mariano’s, Target and Walmart, using the same store locations each time. These stores were chosen for their large footprint in Chicago and because most of our items were available at all four.<br><br>Comparisons are made with shelf prices to remove the variability of occasional sales.</div> </div><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-500000" name="html-embed-module-500000"></a><div class="flourish-embed flourish-quiz" data-src="visualisation/27515435"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/27515435/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="quiz visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div><p></p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2025/07/18/supermarket-super-pain-trump-campaign-food-prices-inflation-tariffs" >We’re tracking grocery prices around Chicago since Trump took office. They’re up and likely to keep rising.</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2025/11/07/grocery-prices-holidays-thanksgiving-christmas-trump-inflation-chicagoans" >Rising grocery prices dampen holiday cheer, how some Chicagoans are coping</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2025/08/15/grocery-prices-cpi-inflation-trump-tariffs" >We’ve been tracking grocery prices in Chicago: Coffee is up and ground beef, too</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>
entries.author: Stephanie Zimmermann

entries.title: Chicago resistance to ICE abuses echoes opposition to Fugitive Slave Act 175 years ago
entries.summary: <p>Jim Gray arrived in chains.</p><p>At the railroad station in Ottawa, Illinois, about 80 miles southwest of Chicago.</p><p>Gray wore leg irons, his arms bound to his sides, and was led by a rope.</p><p>It was Oct 19, 1859.</p><p>The month before he had escaped from slavery in New Madrid, Missouri. Caught by an Illinois sheriff "in sympathy with the slave owners," Gray was being returned to bondage. A crowd awaited him, including a local merchant named John Hossack, an immigrant from Scotland.</p><p>"What crime has he committed?" Hossack shouted. "Has he done anything but want to be free?"</p><p>A question that echoes through the years and across the country today. With federal immigration agents this past year prowling Democratic cities — Los Angeles, Chicago, Minneapolis — kidnapping Latino individuals and dragging them off to exile, and billions being pumped into immigration enforcement, gearing up to grab more people and confine them to enormous facilities now being constructed nationwide, it's impossible not to think of the Fugitive Slave Act, the 1850 law that also created a federal force tasked with snaring people for the crime of wanting to live in freedom.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-460000" name="module-460000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Opinion bug</div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h2>Opinion</h2></div> </div><p>There was already a law, the Fugitive Slave Act of 1793, empowering owners to retrieve their chattel from the North. But Southerners were upset that California was being admitted to the union as a free state. The Fugitive Slave Act of 1850 was a sop to them, meting out punishment to anyone helping Blacks escape slavery, and creating monetary incentives for agents bringing escapees back. The law gave bite to the slave drivers' bark.</p><p>Then as now, local communities fiercely resisted this federal intrusion into their constitutional rights. Then as now, street clashes erupted as national law and human decency faced off against each other. This being February — Black History Month — and with the Trump administration waging war on Black History, scrubbing it from the Smithsonian, from college campuses and federal websites in an attempt to declare the civil rights struggle an unmentionable blot upon enforced patriotic zeal, it seemed important to explore the subject in depth, while we still enjoy the right to do so.</p><p>"All historical analogies are the same," said Matthew Pinsker, a history professor and director of the House Divided Project at Dickinson College. "There's always some similarities and plenty of differences. This is a battle between the national administration and blue state governments. In the Fugitive Slave days, it was a battle between Washington and Northern states, which passed laws called 'personal liberty laws' that were like the sanctuary city laws that Trump is trying to overturn."</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/photography/2025/12/18/midway-blitz-chicago-immigration-raids-photography-photos" >The most pivotal moments of Operation Midway Blitz, captured by Sun-Times photographers</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>Hundreds of Ottawa residents showed up for Gray's hearing the next day in the courtroom of Justice Dean Caton, who ruled that while Gray had broken no Illinois law, the Fugitive Slave Act demanded he go to Springfield to face charges.</p><p>Gray never got there.</p><p>As a marshal began to lead Gray from the courthouse, local men sprang into action. The officer was restrained, while Hossack grabbed Gray by the elbow.</p><p>"If you want liberty, run!" Hossack urged, dragging Gray from the courthouse. They jumped a fence, climbed into a waiting carriage, and were sped out of town.</p><p>Gray escaped north to Canada. But Hossack was arrested and sent to stand trial in federal court in Chicago.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-900000" name="image-900000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/298d991/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1162x652+0+564/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe8%2F1f%2F89fc6f4f4c6abd826c5980ad6450%2F89531849-4198501963509357-1584201560462721024-n.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/44cbd2d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1162x652+0+564/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe8%2F1f%2F89fc6f4f4c6abd826c5980ad6450%2F89531849-4198501963509357-1584201560462721024-n.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e198501/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1162x652+0+564/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe8%2F1f%2F89fc6f4f4c6abd826c5980ad6450%2F89531849-4198501963509357-1584201560462721024-n.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="John Hossack." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e198501/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1162x652+0+564/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe8%2F1f%2F89fc6f4f4c6abd826c5980ad6450%2F89531849-4198501963509357-1584201560462721024-n.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/9f1ce71/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1162x652+0+564/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe8%2F1f%2F89fc6f4f4c6abd826c5980ad6450%2F89531849-4198501963509357-1584201560462721024-n.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e198501/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1162x652+0+564/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe8%2F1f%2F89fc6f4f4c6abd826c5980ad6450%2F89531849-4198501963509357-1584201560462721024-n.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>John Hossack.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Provided courtesy of the Ottawa Historical and Scouting Heritage Museum.</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3>Chicago’s resistance. Strong then, strong now</h3><p>Resistance to the Fugitive Slave Act was particularly strong in Chicago, the city "a sinkhole of abolition" in the words of one downstate editor. A hub of actual railroads, it was also a center for the Underground Railroad, an informal confederation hurrying those escaping slavery north to Canada. When a slave catcher arrived at Chicago in October, 1850, he was informed that his safety could not be guaranteed, and the enslaved servant he had brought with him was helped to escape.</p><p>The same month, the Chicago Common Council — predecessor of the City Council — passed a law condemning the Fugitive Slave Act as "cruel and unjust" and ordering the police force — nine men at the time — "not to render any assistance for the arrest of fugitive slaves."</p><p>Uncannily similar to the challenge Mayor Brandon Johnson would face 175 years later: how much cooperation must local government give to federal authorities enforcing a despised and unjust law? The council in 1850 minced no words, damning any free state representatives supporting the bill as "fit only to be ranked with the traitors, Benedict Arnold, and Judas Iscariot who betrayed his Lord and master for thirty pieces of silver."</p><p>Last October, the City Council passed a similar, if less florid, resolution, focused on trying to protect children from traumatic seizure by ICE agents and urging citizens to report the misconduct they witness.</p><p>What was motivating Chicago to push back against the Fugitive Slave Act? While its tempting to just superimpose Chicago's current sanctuary city liberalism onto the mid-19th century city, that wasn't the case. There were only 323 Black people living in Chicago in 1850 — about 1% of the population. Illinois had passed its own "Black Laws" in 1848, forbidding the immigration of free Blacks into the state and, as amended in 1853, forbidding Black visitors from spending more than 10 nights in the city.</p><p>"These protectors of fugitive slaves raised no objection to the exclusion of Negro testimony against a white person in the courts of law," historian Bessie Louise Pierce noted in 1940. "They seemed to see no inconsistencies in providing a separate section in the theaters for Negroes, and in segregating the races in the common schools."</p><p>To whites, this was more about protecting their own rights than the rights of Black Chicagoans.</p><p>"In a state like Illinois, there were people who cared about free Black residents, but there were an awful lot of white people who cared mostly about personal liberty and state and local rights," said Pinsker, whose newly published book "Boss Lincoln" examines the 16th president's mastery of grassroots politics "They didn't want the federal government or Southern slave owners telling them how to run their own lives... you can see a similar emotion rising in a place like Minneapolis, when they feel like masked federal agents [are] roving around the city, picking up people regardless of whether they are criminals or illegal, but just because of the color of their skin."</p><h3>‘A federalism battle’</h3><p>The issue has already been settled, legally.</p><p>"It's a federalism battle," said Pinsker. "Can states be forced to enforce federal law? That's something the Supreme Court has weighed in on multiple times, and they said no. The sanctuary city advocates are probably going to win in court on the same principles that draw all the way back to Fugitive Slave days."</p><p>If history is a guide, ICE loses.</p><p>"Frankly, this is a historical analogy that should concern the Trump administration," said Pinsker. "Despite all the talk of the Fugitive Slave law being draconian, it was an abject failure. The moral revulsion of Northerners against it stopped it from being enforced... the decade from its passage and the Civil War, there were very few and scattered successful episodes. Most Southerners felt it was a complete failure."</p><p>History is made by individuals standing up to be counted. Renee Good and Alex Pretti now, John Hossack back then.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-c30000" name="image-c30000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/69d1ba1/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5028x2822+0+265/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fec%2F28%2Fc70cfedd425baf83934aee8fa734%2F2257497538.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/733b00f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5028x2822+0+265/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fec%2F28%2Fc70cfedd425baf83934aee8fa734%2F2257497538.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/231e4b5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5028x2822+0+265/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fec%2F28%2Fc70cfedd425baf83934aee8fa734%2F2257497538.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="A photograph of 37-year-old Alex Pretti can be seen at a makeshift memorial in the area where he was shot dead by federal immigration agents earlier in the day in Minneapolis, Minnesota, on January 24, 2026. Federal immigration agents shot dead a man in Minneapolis on Saturday, in the second fatal shooting of a civilian during the Trump administration's unprecedented operation in the city, sparking fresh protests and outrage from state officials. The death came less than three weeks after US citizen Renee Good was shot and killed by an ICE officer. (Photo by ROBERTO SCHMIDT / AFP via Getty Images) ORG XMIT: 776440446" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/231e4b5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5028x2822+0+265/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fec%2F28%2Fc70cfedd425baf83934aee8fa734%2F2257497538.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c59b2ed/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5028x2822+0+265/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fec%2F28%2Fc70cfedd425baf83934aee8fa734%2F2257497538.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/231e4b5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5028x2822+0+265/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fec%2F28%2Fc70cfedd425baf83934aee8fa734%2F2257497538.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>A photograph Alex Pretti, 37, is placed at a memorial near where he was shot dead in Minneapolis. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Roberto Schmidt/Getty</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Hossack's trial began Feb. 28, 1860 in the courtroom of Judge Thomas Drummond on Clark Street. Testimony began with Richard Phillipps, Gray's former owner.</p><p>"That boy belonged to me," he testified. "I bought him and paid for him."</p><p>The cost? One thousand dollars.</p><p>Hossack was found guilty. He had the right to make a statement before sentencing and didn't let the opportunity go to waste.</p><h3>Hossack addresses the court</h3><p>"It may appear strange to your Honor that I have no sense of guilt," he began, explaining he came "from the tyranny of the Old World" finding himself "a stranger in a strange land."</p><p>He came over to dig the canal, then went into business.</p><p>"I am one of the men who have made Chicago what it is today, having shipped some of the first grain that was exported from this city." Hossack said. "I am, Sir, one of the pioneers of Illinois, who have gone through the many hardships of the settlement of a new country. I have spent upon it my best days, the strength of my manhood. I have eleven children, who are natives of this my adopted country. No living man, Sir, has greater interest in its welfare; and it is because I am opposed to carrying out wicked and ungodly laws, and love the freedom of my country, that I stand before you today."</p><p>Like those opposing ICE today, he knew what his freedom was based upon.</p><p>"Sir, I place myself upon the Constitution, in the presence of a nation who have the Declaration of Independence read to them every Fourth of July, and profess to believe it. In the presence of civilized man, I hold up the Constitution of my adopted country as clear from the blood of men, and from a tyranny that would make crowned heads blush. The parties who prostitute the Constitution to the support of slavery are traitors — traitors not only to the liberties of millions of enslaved countrymen, but traitors to the Constitution itself which they have sworn to support. A foreigner upon your soil, I go not to the platforms of contending parties to find truth. I go, Sir, to the Constitution of my country: the word slave is not to be found."</p><p>He quoted the prosecutor claiming it was ungrateful of Hossack to find protection under American law, yet disobey it:</p><p>"Surely, I have been protected. The fish in the rivers, the quail in the stubble, the deer in the forest, have been protected. Shall I join hands with those who make wicked laws, in crushing out the poor Black man, for whom there is no protection but in the grave, where the wicked cease from troubling, and the weary are at rest?... As a man who had fled from the crushing aristocracy of my native land, how could I support a worse aristocracy in this land?"</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-540000" name="image-540000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ce40497/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1264x709+0+508/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F98%2F9c%2Fe53dfd604bcea680dd4a6a04a8ae%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-10-at-8-33-35-am.png 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/dcf632c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1264x709+0+508/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F98%2F9c%2Fe53dfd604bcea680dd4a6a04a8ae%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-10-at-8-33-35-am.png 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0322b31/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1264x709+0+508/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F98%2F9c%2Fe53dfd604bcea680dd4a6a04a8ae%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-10-at-8-33-35-am.png" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="John Hossack's speech." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0322b31/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1264x709+0+508/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F98%2F9c%2Fe53dfd604bcea680dd4a6a04a8ae%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-10-at-8-33-35-am.png 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7085e19/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1264x709+0+508/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F98%2F9c%2Fe53dfd604bcea680dd4a6a04a8ae%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-10-at-8-33-35-am.png 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0322b31/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1264x709+0+508/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F98%2F9c%2Fe53dfd604bcea680dd4a6a04a8ae%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-10-at-8-33-35-am.png" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>John Hossack’s speech.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Screenshot</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>He quoted the Fugitive Slave Act, mandating that reaching free soil did not end a person's slavery.</p><p>"That is the provision that is claimed transforms the government into a monster of iniquity," Hossack said. "How these three or four lines can transform this government, ordained to secure justice, into a mean tool to aid the plunderers of cradles, the destroyers of home, the ravishers of women, and the oppressors of men, to carry on their hellish work — how it can do this thing, I cannot see."</p><p>At times, Hossack seemed to speak across the years to our present administration and its masked agents.</p><p>"Sir, no law can be enacted so bad but that it will find men deluded or base enough to execute it. The law of Egypt that consigned the new-born babe to the slaughter found tools for its execution. The bloody decree of Herod found men ready to obey the law of the country, though it commanded the slaughter of the innocents of a province, Sir, tell me not of men ready and willing to execute the law! My Redeemer, whose name I am hardly worthy to speak, and yet whose name is all my trust, although he knew no sin, yet he was crucified by law."</p><p>He continued.</p><p>"This law so plainly tramples upon the divine law, that it cannot be binding upon any human being under any circumstances to obey it. The law that bids me do to other men as I would have other men do to me, is too plain, too simple to be misunderstood."</p><p>Hossack asks a question that rings today:</p><p>"What country is this? Can it be that I live in a land boasting of freedom, of morality, of Christianity? How long, O, how long, shall the people bow down and worship this great image set up in this nation?"</p><p>And he ends by noting, presciently:</p><p>"When the history of the great struggle shall be candidly written, the rescuers of Jim Gray will be considered as having done honor to God, to humanity, and to themselves."</p><p>Hossack faced a $1,000 fine and six months in jail. Judge Drummond gave him 10 days and fined him $100, which citizens of Chicago promptly paid. Chicago feted him as a hero during his captivity — Mayor John Wentworth sprung him, temporarily, to go for a carriage ride and invited him to his home to dinner. Abolitionists turned Hossack's speech into a handbill and distributed it nationwide, and it <a class="Link" href="https://readingroo.ms/1/3/9/8/13987/13987-h/13987-h.htm" target="_blank" >lives online today.</a> Sadly, the speech still makes for relevant reading.</p>
entries.author: Neil Steinberg

entries.title: Man beaten and robbed at gunpoint in West Loop
entries.summary: <p>A man was beaten and robbed at gunpoint Thursday afternoon in the West Loop, according to Chicago police.</p><p>The 49-year-old man was standing near the sidewalk in the 200 block of North Peoria Street around 4:25 p.m. when two individuals approached him and demanded his belongings, police said in a statement. </p><p>One of them pointed a firearm at the man while the other beat him, police said. Both took items from the man and fled in an SUV.</p><p>The man declined medical attention, officials said. Area 3 detectives were investigating. </p>

>Grocery prices in Chicago have climbed double digits over the last year</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-t/" target="_blank" >Stephanie Zimmermann</a></h5><p><b>Tracking trends</b>: It has been more than a year since the Sun-Times started tracking the monthly price of 35 common grocery items at Jewel-Osco, Mariano’s, Target and Walmart. The verdict? What went up mostly didn’t come down.</p><p><b>Our cart</b>: At Chicago’s largest grocery chain Jewel-Osco, 18 items went up in price, 15 stayed the same and two dropped over the past 13 months. At Walmart, many of the 35 items on our list dropped in price more often than they rose, compared to one year ago. The prices of our items at Mariano’s and Target mostly increased or stayed flat.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: President Donald Trump famously said during his 2024 campaign he’d get prices down "starting on Day 1" of his presidency. And high grocery prices played an outsized role in the presidential election, with many voters reportedly saying they were "very concerned" about food costs.</p><p><b>Take our quiz</b>: See if you can guess the shelf price of items in our cart during a recent trip to Jewel. Take our interactive quiz, and read our full report on climbing grocery prices <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-i/" target="_blank" ><b>here</b></a>.</p><hr><p></p><h4> LET’S HEAR FROM YOU 🗣️</h4><p><b>How do you save money while grocery shopping? rights laws for years, whistleblower and HUD say</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-k/" target="_blank" >Lizzie Kane</a></h5><p><b>Alleged violations</b>: Records show the Chicago Housing Authority violated federal disability laws and the civil rights of residents for at least eight years — leading to negotiations for a voluntary compliance agreement between the CHA and the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. Amanda Motyka, a senior manager of compliance at the housing authority, is now sounding the alarm, again.</p><p><b>The complaint</b>: The filing, viewed by the Sun-Times, was sent last week to the agency’s operating chairman, board and members of senior leadership. It was also submitted to the CHA’s inspector general and HUD. Motyka wrote that she made the complaint to "shine a light on the dysfunction of CHA’s handling of public housing’s reasonable accommodations," and three senior leaders were "complicit in the denial and violation of hundreds of CHA residents’ civil rights."</p><p><a class="Link" low-income families toward hefty loans</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-b/" target="_blank" >Mary Norkol</a></h5><p><b>College costs</b>: Loyola University Chicago and DePaul University are among a few dozen colleges across the country that appear to favor wealthier families when offering financial aid packages, a new report finds.</p><p><b>The report</b>: The two Chicago universities were named in a report released Thursday by the progressive think tank New America, alleging they are among 41 colleges nationwide that push a large share of lower-income families to take out hefty loans to cover college costs while offering attractive scholarships to wealthier families with high-achieving students.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-n/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>PUBLIC SAFETY ✶</h4><p></p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" style="line-height: inherit; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 20px; margin-left: 24px; padding: 0px; list-style-type: disc;" id="rte-9aedafb3-08e4-11f1-a0e9-5f39b3479631"><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-p/" target="_blank" ><b>Educators charged with sex abuse</b></a>: Two Evanston/Skokie School District 65 employees have been charged with sexually abusing minors, according to court documents and district officials.<br></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-x/" target="_blank" ><b>Murders allegedly linked</b></a>: Two assailants who allegedly left a 22-year-old man dead in a Lake View street after shooting him and fleeing in his car Wednesday apparently gunned down another man an hour later and 12 miles away in Bronzeville, according to police reports.<br></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-m/" target="_blank" ><b>Police staffing study</b></a>: A much-anticipated study on Chicago police staffing urges more hiring to better respond to community needs and offers a new model for how to best deploy officers with the resources available. City Council commissioned the study in February 2024 to find ways to close gaps between police response times in different neighborhoods.</li></ul><hr><p></p><h4>IMMIGRATION ✶</h4><div prosecutor to investigate ICE, feds involved in shootings</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-a/" target="_blank" >Violet Miller</a></h5><p><b>Call to action</b>: Cook County Board President Toni Preckwinkle, along with more than half of the county’s commissioners, called on Cook County State’s Attorney Eileen O'Neill Burke to file charges against federal immigration agents involved in shootings that took place last year in the Chicago area. Burke says her office has no jurisdiction to file such charges.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: The county commissioners' statement points to the fatal shooting of Silverio Villegas González, who was shot by federal immigration agents last September in suburban Franklin Park. It also points to the shooting that wounded Marimar Martinez, who survived after being shot multiple times by a federal agent last year.</p><p><b>In other news</b>: A Cicero small business owner <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-f/" target="_blank" >is suing Trump officials after Facebook shut down a popular page tracking immigration activity</a> in the Danny Davis</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-yh/" target="_blank" >Chip Mitchell</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-yk/" target="_blank" >Mitchell Armentrout</a></h5><p><b>7th District drama</b>: Developer Jason Friedman, a white Democrat running in a Chicago-area congressional district that’s had Black representation for a half century, has leapt far ahead of the competition in fundraising after reaping huge sums from finance, real estate and law interests. Friedman is vying for the 7th District seat held by U.S. Rep. Danny K. Davis, who has represented the district since 1997.</p><p><b>Donor base</b>: Friedman, of River North, has raised nearly three times more than his closest rival among <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-yu/" target="_blank" >13 Democratic candidates</a> in the March 17 primary, federal campaign disclosure records show. Friedman’s donor base is drawing criticism from candidates who say it will compromise his ability to represent parts of the district excluded from that sort of wealth. </p><p><b>More election news</b>: <br></p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" style="line-height: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px; margin-left: 24px; padding: 0px; list-style-type: disc;" id="rte-9aee24e4-08e4-11f1-a0e9-5f39b3479631"><li>Seven underdog candidates seeking retiring U.S. Sen. class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-tu/" target="_blank" >Vintage photo booth studio opens for analog fans</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-il/" target="_blank" >Mariah Rush</a></h5><p>In 2001, Anthony Vizzari met his future wife, Andrea, at her Wicker Park apartment. He was an undergraduate student and she worked in advertising. The two bonded over collecting and digging through estate sales for fun.</p><p>Now, the duo has opened what they say is Chicago’s first vintage photo booth studio, just blocks away from where the couple met 25 years ago.</p><p>The Strip Club Photobooth Studio at 1702 N. Damen Ave. boasts eleven photo booths — six vintage-inspired digital and five vintage analog — in the 2,000-square-foot space, the former home of Bellows Film Lab. People and pets alike are welcome to come and pay $7 for a turn in a booth.</p><p>Since 2007, the Vizzaris have been designing and restoring photo booths under their company, A & A Studios, based in Lyons, Illinois. It operates more than 50 booths in businesses in Chicago, at bars and venues such as Replay, Hopsmith Tavern and Schuba’s Tavern.</p><p>With the Strip Club, the Vizzaris are aiming for Gen Z audiences. Photo booths there vary in age, with some dating back to the 1940s and 1950s.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wykhtlt-l-ir/" target="_blank" ><b>READ entries.author: Matt Moore

entries.title: Man stabbed on CTA Green Line train near 47th Street
entries.summary: <p>A man was stabbed on a CTA Green Line train Thursday night on the South Side, according to Chicago police.</p><p>The man, 44, was riding the train about 10:45 p.m. when someone swung a sharp object at him, police said in a statement. Authorities arrived to the 47th Street station, in the 300 block of West 47th Street, and found the man with face injuries.</p><p>He was taken to the University of Chicago Medical Center and listed in fair condition, police said. </p><p>Area 1 detectives were investigating.</p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: CPD squad car collides with CTA bus in Ukrainian Village; 2 officers among 3 hospitalized
entries.summary: <p>Two officers were among three people hospitalized after a Chicago police squad car collided with a CTA bus early Friday in Ukrainian Village on the Northwest Side, according to Chicago police.</p><p>The officers were traveling south on Hoyne Avenue when they "came into contact" with the CTA bus going west on Chicago Avenue around 12:15 a.m., police said in a statement.</p><p>A passenger on the bus was taken to Stroger Hospital with a minor injury and was in good condition, police said. Two officers were hospitalized for observation and were in good condition.</p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Residente de Chicago demanda a funcionarios de Trump por cerrar grupo de Facebook de avistamientos de ICE
entries.summary: <p>La fundadora de uno de los grupos de Facebook más grandes para rastrear e informar sobre la actividad federal de inmigración en el área de Chicago durante el Operativo Midway Blitz de la administración de Trump está contraatacando después de que Facebook deshabilitó la página en octubre.</p><p>En una <a class="Link" href="https://www.thefire.org/sites/default/files/2026/02/Verified%20Complaint%20-%20Rosado%20v.%20Bondi.pdf" target="_blank" >demanda presentada el miércoles</a>, la propietaria de un negocio pequeño en Cicero, Kassandra “Kae” Rosado, alegó que la Fiscal General Pam Bondi y la Secretaria del Departamento de Seguridad Nacional (DHS) Kristi Noem obligaron a Facebook a que eliminara el popular grupo “ICE Sighting-Chicagoland”, violando los derechos de la Primera Enmienda de Rosado.</p><p>“Los demandados tomaron represalias contra el grupo de Facebook de Rosado por la simple razón de que al gobierno no le gusta el discurso que se comparte. Pero el gobierno no tiene un interés legítimo en ‘detener a actores privados de hablar como deseen’ para ‘inclinar el debate público en una dirección preferida’”, dice la demanda.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-8e0000" name="module-8e0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>Rosado comenzó el grupo en enero de 2025 para mantener informados a individuos y pequeños negocios sobre dónde estaba operando el Servicio de Inmigración y Aduanas (ICE) en Chicago, según la demanda. El grupo estaba inicialmente compuesto de compañeros dueños de negocios y amigos y familiares de Rosado. Los miembros del grupo aumentaron en septiembre a medida que la aplicación de la ley de inmigración de ICE aumentaba en la ciudad y sus suburbios circundantes.</p><p>Para octubre, el grupo contaba con casi 100,000 miembros, con miles de publicaciones y comentarios por día de miembros compartiendo información sobre encuentros violentos y arrestos en toda la ciudad, según la demanda.</p><p>Pero el 12 de octubre, la activista de derecha y aliada de Trump, Laura Loomer, <a class="Link" href="https://x.com/LauraLoomer/status/1977345952718438707" target="_blank" >etiquetó a Noem y Bondi en una publicación</a> afirmando que el grupo de Facebook y otras páginas similares “están poniendo en riesgo la vida de las personas”. Al día siguiente, Loomer <a class="Link" href="https://x.com/LauraLoomer/status/1977812771799461893?s=20" target="_blank" >dijo en una publicación</a> que una fuente del Departamento de Justicia (DOJ) le informó que habían contactado a ejecutivos de Meta, la empresa matriz de Facebook, “para decirles que necesitan remover estas páginas de seguimiento de ICE de la plataforma”.</p><p>Noem y Bondi anunciaron la eliminación del grupo de Facebook en sus cuentas de redes sociales el 14 de octubre. “Los radicales anti-ICE están utilizando aplicaciones de redes sociales para acosar, amenazar y aterrorizar a los valientes hombres y mujeres de ICE y a sus familias”, dijo Noem <a class="Link" href="https://x.com/Sec_Noem/status/1978182132414448008?s=20" target="_blank" >en la publicación.</a> Según la demanda, Facebook notificó a Rosado que el grupo fue deshabilitado porque “violó los Estándares Comunitarios en múltiples ocasiones”.</p><p>Mientras el grupo estaba activo, dice la demanda, los moderadores de Facebook habían eliminado cinco publicaciones en el grupo que no fueron creadas ni aprobadas por Rosado o sus moderadores. Además, la demanda afirma que Facebook le había aconsejado previamente a Rosado que “sólo había identificado este puño de ‘violaciones de participantes’ a sus reglas, las cuales ‘no dañan a su grupo’”.</p><p>“Al censurar nuestro grupo, el gobierno continúa deteriorando nuestra confianza”, dijo Rosado en un <a class="Link" href="https://www.thefire.org/news/fire-sues-bondi-noem-censoring-facebook-group-and-app-reporting-ice-activity" target="_blank" >comunicado</a>. “No sólo silenciaron mi voz, sino las voces de casi 100,000 otros miembros de la comunidad”.</p><p>Rosado presentó la demanda junto con Mark Hodges, residente de Indiana que creó la aplicación Eyes Up, que permitía a los usuarios grabar, almacenar de manera segura y ver videos de agentes de ICE cometiendo posibles violaciones a los derechos civiles. Según la demanda, Apple removió la aplicación de la App Store en octubre, supuestamente después de presiones del gobierno federal, violando el derecho protegido por la Primera Enmienda de Hodges de grabar a las fuerzas del orden en público.</p><p>El Departamento de Justicia, Apple y Meta no respondieron de inmediato a las solicitudes de comentarios.</p><p>En un comunicado, la Subsecretaria de DHS, Tricia McLaughlin, dijo: “Las aplicaciones de seguimiento de ICE ponen en peligro la vida de los hombres y mujeres de las fuerzas del orden mientras persiguen a terroristas, pandillas violentas y grupos criminales”.</p><p>“Pero, por supuesto, FIRE presenta esta decisión correcta de Apple para eliminar estas aplicaciones, como si estuviera capitulando ante la presión, en lugar de ayudar a prevenir un mayor daño a los oficiales federales", agregó.</p><p>La demanda pide a la corte que declare que la coerción ejercida por Bondi y Noem sobre Facebook y Apple suprimió un discurso desfavorable, lo cual viola la Primera Enmienda.</p><p>“Los demandantes presentan este caso para preservar el carácter fundamental de nuestro país como una nación libre, pidiendo a esta corte que proteja el derecho básico de la Primera Enmienda a compartir información sobre nuestro gobierno y sus actividades”, dice la demanda.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Elleiana Green

entries.title: Previewing and predicting this weekend's top high school basketball games
entries.summary: <p>The IHSA tournament seeds and state brackets highlight and gobble up the headlines this week. But there is still regular-season basketball to be played this weekend, including a couple of big rivalries, a huge conference showdown in the Northern Lake County Conference and the Public League playoffs.</p><p>Here is a look ahead to a few of the top games with picks and previews.</p><p><i>Last week’s record: 4-1</i><br><i>Season record: 28-10</i></p><h3>No. 12 Evanston (23-5) at No. 20 New Trier (21-7), Friday</h3><p>Evanston has clinched the Central Suburban League South title, so another date with rival New Trier will get the juices flowing again for coach Mike Ellis’ team just prior to state tournament play.</p><p>New Trier, meanwhile, gets another crack at a team that has had its number. The Trevians have yet to beat Evanston in their new gym, which opened in 2023. Since Ellis took over the Evanston program, the Wildkits are 24-10 against their biggest rival.</p><p>When these two met last, a 67-59 Evanston win, New Trier was just beginning to learn how to play without point guard and leading scorer Christopher Kirkpatrick. The Trevians have responded of late, winning eight out of their last nine as Kirkpatrick remains saddled with an injury.</p><p>New Trier boasts outstanding balance in both their size and scoring. Danny Houlihan, a 6-4 shooter who has signed with High Point, leads New Trier with 16 points a game, but 6-7 freshman Denym Wallace, 6-4 junior Elton Jaegerskog, 6-5 junior Matthew Logue and 6-4 Max Vogel are all capable scorers and offer versatility.</p><p>How balanced is Evanston? The Wildkits are stacked with double-figure scorers who all average between 10-13 points, including Dion Lane, Vito Rocca, Timi Ogunsanya, Ben Ojala and Tate Schroeder.</p><p><i>The pick: Evanston 65, New Trier 60</i></p><h3>Wauconda (21-7) at Grayslake Central (20-8), Friday</h3><h3></h3><p>The Northern Lake County Conference comes down to this late-season battle. So let's shine a little light on basketball in this far-reaching area.</p><p>Grayslake Central did stumble earlier this week in an upset loss to Grant. Thus, it’s a must-win situation for the Rams as they now sit one game behind Wauconda.</p><p>Wauconda overcame a 44-36 deficit with just 2:25 to play to win the first matchup back on Jan. 14, a 47-44 come-from-behind thriller.</p><p>Alex Ortega has emerged as one of the top scoring threats in Lake County. He leads a Wauconda team that can really put points on the board. With Ortega putting up 18.6 points and 3.7 assists a game, the Bulldogs have scored 65 or more points in 17 games this season. Ortega and Leo Brinias (10.2 ppg, 3.7 apg) form a solid scoring and distributing combo in the backcourt.</p><p>The hope is that both 6-6 Austin Carlsen (14.3 ppg, 7.4 rpg), a real underrated player in the Chicago area, and shooting guard Tony Salemi (16.8 ppg) are back and healthy for Friday’s showdown. Carlsen missed Wauconda’s last game while Salemi has missed six games.</p><p>For those who haven’t been paying attention, this is the fifth straight 20-plus win season for coach Brian Centella and Grayslake Central. This year’s group is headed by a trio of seniors on the perimeter: 6-3 Cole Halverson 13 ppg, 5 rpg), Alex Granville (13 ppg, 2.5 apg) and point guard Carson Woods (12 ppg, 4.5 rpg, 3 apg).</p><p>Can Grayslake Central slow down a Wauconda team that would like to play in the 70s? The good news for Wauconda is the score was low last time but still pulled out the win.</p><p>This one will be a fun one that should go down to the wire again.</p><p><i>The pick: Grayslake Central 52, Wauconda 50</i></p><h3>No. 13 Fremd (23-2) at Hersey (17-6), Friday</h3><h3></h3><p>Hersey is out of the MSL West conference race, but it can play the spoiler role in this one while building some momentum for state tournament play. Fremd is all alone atop the league but sits just one game ahead of Palatine.</p><p>Fremd won the first matchup 67-63 behind a balanced attack featuring Rafael Pinto (19 pts), Chase Nelson (18 pts), Jordan Williams (16 pts) and Tommy Moffett (15 pts).</p><p>Hersey’s Charlie Pomis has put together a heck of a season. The athletic senior wing is putting up 18 points to go with nearly six rebounds and over three assists a game. He scored 20 in the first meeting, while senior teammate Logan Luxen added 16.</p><p>These are two teams that appear to be headed in different directions.</p><p>After starting the season 11-0, Hersey has gone just 5-6 since. The Huskies are at home and could certainly use a pick-me-up.</p><p>Meanwhile, Fremd is on an emotional high following an impressive run of frantic finishes in beating quality competition. In the past two weeks the Vikings have knocked off Palatine, Rolling Meadows, New Trier and Niles North in tight ones, including two of those wins coming in overtime.</p><p><i>The pick: Fremd 62, Hersey 57</i></p><h3>Oswego (20-8) at Oswego East (18-9), Friday</h3><h3></h3><p>Is it the biggest of games in the big picture? No. Neither team is ranked or in conference contention and the seeds have been established. But it’s a rivalry between two teams headed towards 20 wins. Plus, the last one between these two was a dandy.</p><p>There is a star attraction in this matchup as well with Oswego East’s Mason Lockett, who is headed to DePaul next year, and Oswego’s Ethan Vahl, one of the top sophomores in the state.</p><p>Oswego East’s record is a bit deceiving with the schedule it has faced. The Wolves have squared off with six ranked teams, going 2-4 in those games. The tandem of Lockett and junior D'Shaun Bolden regularly combine for 35-plus points a game.</p><p>While the lack of depth can catch up to the Wolves, Oswego has established some depth of its own and balance beyond Vahl’s 21.3 points, 7.1 rebounds and 3.2 assists a game.</p><p>The last time these two met back in December, Oswego’s 59-52 win in overtime was considered an upset. After all, it ended an Oswego East win streak over Oswego at 16 straight. But fast-forward one month later and it’s a flip of the coin. That’s how far Oswego has come.</p><p>It would be a surprise if this doesn’t turn into another fantastic finish. But Oswego has been playing the better basketball of late.</p><p><i>The pick: Oswego 62, Oswego East 60</i></p><h3>Kenwood (16-7) at No. 18 Young (21-6), Saturday</h3><h3></h3><p>Among the city quarterfinal games this weekend, this figures to be the best — at least on paper.</p><p>Kenwood edged Morgan Park and Young escaped with an overtime win over Perspectives-Leadership on Thursday to set up the first meeting between these two this season.</p><p>Young has two big things going for it: Marquis Clark and the confidence that’s grown from a 11-game winning streak.</p><p>Clark is the city’s best player. The high-scoring guard is headed to Tennessee and has takeover ability. The Dolphins haven’t experienced defeat since late December and have lost just two games to in-state teams — Warren and St. Ignatius.</p><p>It’s been a whirlwind of a season for Kenwood with ups and downs. Nonetheless, this is a dangerous team, thanks to the junior tandem of Damari Stephens and Osiris Bell.</p><p><i>The pick: Young 72, Kenwood 68</i></p><h3>Joliet West (18-8) at No. 7 Homewood-Flossmoor (23-3), Saturday</h3><p>Alright, let’s see how much Joliet West has improved?</p><p>The Tigers are clearly playing their best basketball of the season. They lost to H-F 58-47 at the Pontiac Holiday Tournament in late December. But they’ve dropped only one game since — to ranked Bolingbrook in overtime.</p><p>This will be an ideal measuring stick for Joliet West, which is led by three double-figure scorers: Aamir Shannon (11 ppg, 5 rpg), the much-improved Ryan Lipke (10 ppg, 6 rpg) and Devin Triplett (10 ppg, 5 rpg). Coach Jeremy Kreiger’s team is playing well enough to sneak up on some teams come regional time.</p><p>H-F has been a model of consistency as the sparkling record shows. That’s possible when you have a point guard like Darrius Hawkins who impacts winning as much as he does. The sophomore sets the tone while averaging 18 points, six assists and 2.5 steals a game.</p><p>Hawkins sets the table for lesser-known but ultra-effective Marvin Douglas (12 ppg, 7 rpg), Danny Ruffin (8.7 ppg, 4.1 apg) and Ethan Jackson (8.7 ppg).</p><p><i>The pick: Homewood-Flossmoor 70, Joliet West 64</i></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-b40000" name="html-embed-module-b40000"></a><iframe title="No Shot Clock, Ep. 201: Conference quick takes" allowtransparency="true" height="150" width="100%" style="border: none; min-width: min(100%, 430px);height:150px;" scrolling="no" data-name="pb-iframe-player" src="https://www.podbean.com/player-v2/?i=5patj-1a40c88-pb&from=pb6admin&share=1&download=1&rtl=0&fonts=Arial&skin=1&font-color=auto&logo_link=episode_page&btn-skin=c73a3a" loading="lazy"></iframe> </div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Joe Henricksen

entries.title: Sophomore forward Charity Bryant's ascent powering Evanston to resurgent season
entries.summary: <p>Near the end of the first quarter of Evanston's 58-33 win over Hinsdale Central, sophomore forward Charity Bryant got going.</p><p>Already leading 10-7, Bryant calmly dribbled down the court and drilled a pull-up three. Then on the next possession, she found senior guard Havana Van Wyk streaking toward the rim. Those two plays show how sklled Bryant is.</p><p>"I think she's the best sophomore that no one talks about," coach Brittanny Johnson said. "I'm hoping that the recognition she's starting to get now will kind of get her a little bit more looks so people start to see that she's a player."</p><p>Bryant's breakout sophomore campaign continued after a stellar 21-point performance against Hinsdale Central. At 6-0, Bryant is a mismatch nightmare for opposing teams. She can see over the top of defenses and deliver accurate, on-time passes to cutting teammates. She's an adept finisher in the paint and sports an impressive shooting stroke.</p><p>Bryant's development is partly why Evanston finished the regular season with a 15-10 record. The Wildkits have close losses to Maine South, Libertyville, Waubonsie Valley and St. Ignatius on their résumé. They also split with a strong Maine South team. That tough schedule will benefit the Wildkits because of their formidable seeding in the IHSA playoffs. They're lumped in with Loyola, Maine South, Glenbrook South and DePaul College Prep as the top seeds above them. </p><p>But the Wildkits' season has been much better than last year's 12-20 campaign.</p><p>"Our goal was really just to be competitive," Johnson said. "We felt like last year we had too many running clock games, so we wanted to come here and end our regular season in a good way."</p><p>Evanston was dominant defensively on Thursday. They suffocated Hinsdale Central's offense, forcing them into untimely miscues and errant shots. Even when the Red Devils had a sliver of daylight, Evanston's length sped them up. Even with holding a 28-17 halftime lead, Johnson thought the team spent the first half adjusting to the Red Devils' extended zone defense. Once Evanston got used to where the traps were going to come from, the Wildkits were able to move the ball effectively and create easy shots all second half.</p><p>"This was a good game to prepare us for [IHSA] playoffs," Bryant said."</p><p>Junior guard Payton King, who made the Central Suburban League All-Conference team, is also an integral piece to the Wildkits' attack. She racked up two steals in the first quarter by correctly reading the defense and pouncing at the right time. She scored eight points on Thursday. She regularly guards the opposing team's best player while playing point guard for Evanston.</p><p>"[I] definitely put in a lot of work in the offseason, so to be rewarded for that meant a lot," King said. "But that's definitely not going to stop me from continuing to work hard."</p><p>King and Bryant — along with 6-2 forward Simone Hewitt, who is a deterrent in the paint and a reliable finisher— give the Wildkits a fearsome duo heading into the IHSA state playoffs. But Bryant's development raises the ceiling of what Evanston can do this season and next year. There aren't many agile forwards with her combination of scoring, passing and dribbling abilities.</p><p>"She's done a way better job in the second half of just utilizing her teammates ... she wants to win so bad," Johnson said. "She can be really dangerous when she shares with all her teammates, because she has great court vision and great IQ. She's just scratching the surface, like it's almost scary how good she could be."<br></p>
entries.author: Kyle Williams

entries.title: Woman dies after being found with no clothes in back of stolen car on North Side, police say
entries.summary: <p>A woman died after she was found with no clothes in the back seat of a stolen car Thursday afternoon in the North Center neighborhood on the North Side, according to police.</p><p>Around 3:15 p.m., a person called 911 and said they found their stolen black Nissan Pathfinder in the 3200 block of North Damen Avenue, Chicago police dispatch records show. </p><p>The woman, 39, was found in the back seat still breathing when first responders arrived and was given CPR, according to police scanner traffic. </p><p>She was taken to the Advocate Illinois Masonic Medical Center where she died, police said in a statement. </p><p>Police said the cause of death for the woman wasn’t immediately known. Detectives were conducting a death investigation.</p><p>The Cook County medical examiner's office has scheduled an autopsy.</p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Should Chicago install roundabouts or more traffic circles? Here's what you told us
entries.summary: <p>We asked readers whether Chicago should be like the suburbs and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/transportation/2026/02/06/roundabouts-traffic-chicago-suburbs-illinois-department-transportation" >install roundabouts</a> or <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/curious-city/2025/07/16/why-chicago-goes-round-and-round-with-traffic-circles" >more traffic circles</a>. Here's what you told us, lightly edited for clarity:</p><p>"Sadly, Chicago drivers are unable to navigate the traffic circles we have now, so adding more would make traffic more dangerous, if that's even possible."<br><i>— Tom Covell</i></p><p>"They'd never do it simply since it will eat into their red light cam money."<br><i>— Graham Stegall </i></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> They can easily be implemented ... creating a safer environment for city residents!"<br><i>— Jaime Duque</i></p><p>"The learning curve is too big, and people will be flattened."<br><i>— Christine Bock</i></p><p>"I live alongside a roundabout in Lake County. ... Before the roundabout, traffic would back up for a quarter to half a mile while waiting to traverse the intersection during rush hours. Now, traffic of three to four cars may accumulate for seconds during the same time spans."<br><i>— Mike Lyne</i></p><p>"Drive the back streets of Rogers Park and get back to us. I'd focus on the streets between Pratt [Boulevard] and Devon [Avenue]. Oof. Oof.
